Don Quixote scoffs, emphasizing the glory of chivalry. Sancho complains of only getting beatings. Don Quixote promises a magic sword. They see two dust clouds, which Don Quixote believes are two armies of giants. Sancho sees only two droves of sheep. Don Quixote names the imaginary armies and their leaders. He charges one "army" (a flock of ewes). The shepherds stone him, breaking his lance, injuring him, and smashing his balsam flask. Sancho finds him injured. Don Quixote blames enchanters for turning armies into sheep. He asks Sancho to check his teeth, then vomits the balsam onto Sancho's beard. Sancho, disgusted, vomits back on Don Quixote. Sancho discovers his alforjas are missing and wants to quit. Don Quixote consoles him, saying good times follow bad. They leave, camping out in the fields.

**Chapter XIX: Of the Shrewd Discourse which Sancho held with his Master, and of the Adventure that Befell him with a Dead Body, together with other Notable Occurrences**
Sancho suggests their misfortunes are due to Don Quixote breaking his oath. Don Quixote admits he forgot. Night falls, they are hungry, and their alforjas are still missing. They see approaching lights and a litter. Sancho is terrified; Don Quixote sees an adventure. He encounters men in white (encamisados) with torches, accompanying a black litter. Don Quixote demands they identify themselves. They refuse. Don Quixote attacks, unhorsing one man and scattering the rest. The fallen man, a licentiate, explains they are priests transporting a body to Segovia. Sancho, meanwhile, loots a mule laden with provisions. Don Quixote is chagrined but accepts the licentiate's explanation. Sancho, having seen his master's "rueful countenance," suggests Don Quixote adopt the name "Knight of the Rueful Countenance." Don Quixote likes the idea. They eat the stolen provisions, but lack wine or water. They hear a constant hammering noise.

**Chapter XX: Of the Unexampled and Unheard-of Adventure which was Achieved by the Valiant Don Quixote of La Mancha with less Peril than any Ever Achieved by any Famous Knight in the World**
Sancho suggests they find water, despite the hammering noise. Don Quixote, taking the noise as a call to adventure, makes a grand speech about reviving knight-errantry and imitating Amadis or Roland. He tells Sancho to wait for three days while he descends into the perilous abyss. Sancho weeps, begs him not to go, and tries to stall by claiming it's almost dawn. When Don Quixote refuses to be deterred, Sancho secretly ties Rocinante's legs with Dapple's halter. Don Quixote, finding his horse unable to move, attributes it to enchantment and agrees to wait for daylight. To pass the time, Sancho begins a long, rambling story about a goatherd and goats crossing a river. Don Quixote loses count of the goats, and Sancho declares the story ended. Sancho discreetly relieves himself in the dark. At dawn, they discover the noise comes from six fulling hammers. Don Quixote is mortified; Sancho laughs. Don Quixote beats Sancho with his pike for the mockery. Don Quixote rationalizes, saying that enchanters disguise things and that his courage was still evident. Sancho, now with renewed fear of his master's madness and beatings, promises to be more respectful. They discuss squire wages, and Don Quixote promises Sancho riches from future kingdoms.

**Chapter XXI: Which Treats of the Exalted Adventure and Rich Prize of Mambrino's Helmet, together with Other Things that Happened to our Invincible Knight**
They encounter a barber wearing his brass basin on his head to shield from rain. Don Quixote immediately identifies it as Mambrino's helmet and charges the barber, who falls from his ass and flees, leaving the basin. Sancho identifies it as a basin. Don Quixote insists it's the enchanted helmet, explaining enchanters alter appearances. Sancho questions this logic, especially in light of past beatings. Don Quixote allows Sancho to swap Dapple's trappings with the barber's ass. Sancho suggests they serve a king or emperor, and Don Quixote agrees, imagining his future as a king. Sancho fantasizes about his wife becoming a queen. Don Quixote outlines the path to fame for knights.

**Chapter XXII: Of the Freedom Don Quixote Conferred on Several Unfortunates who against their Will were being Carried where they had no wish to go**
Don Quixote and Sancho encounter a chain of galley slaves being escorted by guards. Don Quixote believes these men are being taken against their will and vows to free them, seeing it as his duty to right wrongs. He questions each prisoner about their crimes, hearing various tales of petty theft, confession under torture, and pimping. Gines de Pasamonte, a notorious criminal and author of his own life story, is among them. Don Quixote, convinced these men are unjustly oppressed, attacks the guards, freeing the galley slaves. The freed slaves, in a display of ingratitude, stone Don Quixote and Sancho, steal Sancho's coat and the basin-helmet, and flee. Don Quixote blames enchanters for their treachery.

**Chapter XXIII: Of what Befell Don Quixote in the Sierra Morena, which was one of the Rarest Adventures Related in this Veracious History**
Don Quixote laments the ingratitude of the galley slaves. Sancho, fearing the Holy Brotherhood, convinces Don Quixote to take refuge in the Sierra Morena. That night, Gines de Pasamonte, the galley slave, steals Dapple from the sleeping Sancho. Sancho wakes to discover Dapple missing and laments bitterly. Don Quixote consoles him, promising him three ass-colts. They discover a valise containing gold crowns and fine linen. Don Quixote finds a memorandum book with a sonnet and a love letter, suggesting the owner is a rejected lover. They then spot a ragged, wild-looking man leaping among the rocks. A goatherd tells them the story of Cardenio, a once noble youth driven mad by love and betrayal, now living in the mountains. Cardenio appears, and Don Quixote tries to engage him. Cardenio, in a mad fit, attacks Don Quixote with a stone, beating him and Sancho before fleeing. Sancho fights the goatherd, whom he blames for not warning them. Don Quixote separates them, still eager to hear Cardenio's story.

**Chapter XXIV: In which is Continued the Adventure of the Sierra Morena**
Cardenio, now lucid, tells Don Quixote and the others his full story. He fell in love with Luscinda. His friend Don Fernando, Duke Ricardo's son, came to his city, saw Luscinda, and fell in love with her. Don Fernando used a trick to send Cardenio away and secretly married Luscinda. At the wedding, Luscinda declared herself Cardenio's wife in a hidden note and attempted suicide with a dagger. Don Fernando, enraged, left. Cardenio, witnessing this, fled to the Sierra Morena, losing his reason intermittently. He ends his tale.

**Chapter XXV: Which Treats of the Strange Things that Happened to the Stout Knight of La Mancha in the Sierra Morena, and of his Imitation of the Penance of Beltenebros**
Don Quixote decides to perform a penance in imitation of Amadis of Gaul, who griered over Oriana's rejection. He explains he must act mad without cause to prove his love for Dulcinea. Sancho questions his sanity, especially regarding Mambrino's helmet (still a basin to him). Don Quixote strips naked and performs somersaults for Sancho, who then leaves on Rocinante to deliver a letter to Dulcinea. Sancho, returning to the inn, meets the curate and barber. He tries to keep his master's location secret but eventually reveals everything. The curate and barber decide to trick Don Quixote into returning home.

**Chapter XXVI: In which are Continued the Refinements wherewith Don Quixote played the part of a Lover in the Sierra Morena**
Don Quixote, alone, debates whether to imitate Roland's furious madness or Amadis's melancholy. He decides on Amadis, praying and carving verses about Dulcinea on trees. Sancho, meanwhile, has encountered the curate and barber. He confesses the truth about Dulcinea's "enchantment" and his master's madness. The curate and barber, having heard Don Quixote's story and Sancho's account, decide to rescue him. They plan for the curate to disguise himself as a distressed damsel and the barber as her squire. Sancho is instructed to tell Don Quixote that Dulcinea commanded him to return.

**Chapter XXVII: Of how the Curate and the Barber Proceeded with their Scheme; together with Other Matters worthy of Record in this Great History**
The curate and barber borrow clothes and create disguises. The innkeeper and his wife, having heard of Don Quixote's madness, confirm his eccentricities. The curate, realizing his disguise as a damsel is indecorous, suggests the barber take the role. Sancho is instructed to lead them to Don Quixote and to lie about delivering the letter to Dulcinea, claiming she is illiterate and gave a verbal command for Don Quixote to come to her. Sancho agrees, hoping this will lead to his master becoming an emperor. They find Don Quixote, still performing his penance. The disguised barber (Dorothea) kneels before him, begging his aid to avenge a giant who usurped her kingdom (Micomicon). Don Quixote grants the boon, promising to restore her. Sancho, still dreaming of his governorship, imagines selling black vassals from Micomicon. The curate and Cardenio, also disguised, watch. The barber's false beard falls off, but the curate quickly reattaches it with a "charm." Don Quixote still believes it's all enchantment.

**Chapter XXVIII: Wherein is Told the Distressed Duenna's Tale of her Misfortunes**
The duchess asks Sancho about his critical remarks about duennas. The Distressed Duenna (the majordomo in disguise), led by Trifaldin (another servant), appears with twelve veiled duennas, all with beards. She recounts her tale: she was governess to Princess Antonomasia of Kandy. Don Clavijo, a gentleman, seduced and married the princess. Queen Maguncia (the princess's mother) died of grief. The giant Malambruno, the queen's cousin, then enchanted Don Clavijo into a crocodile and Antonomasia into a brass ape, and inflicted beards on all the duennas, stating that only Don Quixote can reverse the enchantment by fighting Malambruno. Don Quixote agrees to the adventure. Sancho is reluctant to travel to Kandy and get a beard shaved. The duke promises Sancho his island if he helps. Don Quixote also demands that Sancho begin his 3,300 lashes for Dulcinea's disenchantment.

**Chapter XXIX: Which Treats of the Droll Device and Method Adopted to Extricate our Love-stricken Knight from the Severe Penance he had Imposed upon Himself**
Doña Rodriguez (the duenna of the house) comes to Don Quixote's room at night, mistaking him for a potential lover, and explains her own grievance: her daughter was seduced by a rich farmer's son who now refuses to marry her, and the duke won't intervene. She also reveals the duchess has two "issues" on her legs, which Don Quixote misinterprets. Suddenly, the duke's servants (the same who disguised as Merlin and others) burst in, flog Doña Rodriguez and pinch Don Quixote as a trick. Don Quixote believes it's enchantment. Meanwhile, Sancho, as governor of Barataria, faces various cases. He cleverly resolves a dispute about a cane containing money and another about a woman defending her purse, banishing a man for idleness. He also deals with a tailor's dispute. These deeds are sent to the duke.

**Chapter XXX: Of Matters Relating and Belonging to this Adventure and to this Memorable History**
Altisidora, feigning death, sings a lament for Don Quixote, blaming his coldness. She claims to have seen devils in hell playing tennis with books, specifically a false "Second Part of Don Quixote." She recovers and admits her "death" was a trick. Don Quixote rejects her again, reaffirming his loyalty to Dulcinea. Don Quixote eventually departs the castle. Sancho is given 200 gold crowns by the majordomo. Altisidora sings a scornful farewell. Don Quixote and Sancho proceed towards Saragossa. They encounter Roque Guinart, a famous highwayman, and his band. Roque's men rob Sancho, but Roque, recognizing Don Quixote, returns the stolen items (except some handkerchiefs). Don Quixote gives Roque moral advice. Roque then helps a young woman, Claudia Jeronima, who shot her lover, Don Vicente Torrellas, for breaking a marriage promise. Roque finds Don Vicente wounded. Claudia, remorseful, faints as Don Vicente dies. Claudia decides to become a nun. Roque writes to a friend in Barcelona to prepare for Don Quixote's arrival.

**Chapter XXXI: Which Treats of Many and Great Matters**
Don Quixote, still recovering from his wounds and the cat incident, is entertained by the duke and duchess. Sancho writes a letter to his wife, Teresa, informing her of his governorship, the duchess's gift, and Dulcinea's disenchantment requiring lashes. Teresa writes back, overjoyed, sending acorns to the duchess and planning to go to court. The page delivers the letters. Don Quixote, Sancho, and the duke and duchess discuss Don Quixote's adventures and the continuing enchantment. Sancho's talk of his family's lineage and the common wisdom of proverbs amuses them.

**Chapter XXXII: Of the Reply Don Quixote gave his Censurer, with Other Incidents, Grave and Droll**
An ecclesiastic at the duke's table criticizes Don Quixote's madness and knight-errantry. Don Quixote defends his profession eloquently, asserting its importance in upholding virtue and justice. Sancho supports his master. The duke, amused by the ecclesiastic's irritation, promises Sancho a government. The ecclesiastic, disgusted, leaves. The duchess's damsels play a trick on Don Quixote, "washing" his beard with lye and soap. Sancho expects similar treatment but dislikes it. Don Quixote is asked to describe Dulcinea, but he says her beauty is beyond words and that she is enchanted. He explains that enchanters persecute him, transforming Dulcinea into a coarse peasant.

**Chapter XXXIII: Of the Delectable Discourse which the Duchess and her Damsels held with Sancho Panza, well worth Reading and Noting**
Sancho, questioned by the duchess, confesses he invented Dulcinea's enchantment to deceive his master and avoid his wrath. The duchess reveals that their enchanters confirm Dulcinea *is* enchanted, despite Sancho's trick. Sancho is confused but accepts this. He recounts his experience in the Cave of Montesinos (a fabricated tale to humor Don Quixote). Sancho then assures the duchess he will be a good governor.

**Chapter XXXIV: Which Relates how they Learned the Way in which they were to Disenchant the Peerless Dulcinea del Toboso, which is one of the Rarest Adventures in this Book**
The duke and duchess plan a new trick. They take Don Quixote hunting. A wild boar appears, and Don Quixote bravely confronts it. Sancho, terrified, climbs a tree, but the branch breaks, leaving him hanging. After the boar is killed, a demon courier appears, announcing that Merlin will reveal the method for Dulcinea's disenchantment. Three triumphal cars arrive, carrying figures of sages. Merlin (the majordomo in disguise) appears and declares that Dulcinea will be disenchanted if Sancho inflicts 3,300 lashes upon his bare buttocks. Sancho refuses vehemently. Altisidora, disguised as the enchanted Dulcinea, appears and pleads with Sancho. Sancho, still resistant, argues about the unfairness. The duke persuades him, promising his island. Sancho agrees, on his own terms (voluntary, no blood drawn, fly-flappers count, Merlin counts). Don Quixote is overjoyed.

**Chapter XXXV: Wherein is Continued the Instruction given to Don Quixote touching the Disenchantment of Dulcinea, together with Other Marvellous Incidents**
Sancho confesses he only gave himself five lashes. The duchess insists on a painful scourge. Sancho writes a letter to Teresa, mentioning his government, the lashes, and a hunting suit for Sanchica. The duchess also writes to Teresa. Later, Trifaldin (the majordomo disguised as a bearded squire) arrives with other bearded duennas. The Distressed Duenna (another disguised servant) tells the story of Princess Antonomasia and Don Clavijo, who were enchanted by the giant Malambruno, and she and her duennas were given beards. Malambruno's wooden horse, Clavileño the Swift, is sent. Sancho refuses to ride it. The duke promises Sancho his island. Sancho and Don Quixote are blindfolded and mounted on Clavileño. Servants blow bellows and use tow to simulate wind and fire. Don Quixote believes they are flying high. Sancho peeks, claiming to see the earth as small as a mustard seed and men like hazelnuts, and that he even dismounted to play with celestial goats. Clavileño explodes, and they fall to the ground. They find a parchment stating the adventure is complete, the duennas are shaved, and Dulcinea will be disenchanted after Sancho's lashes.

(This chapter, as provided, seems to be a continuation of the captive's story which began in what the text refers to as "Chapter XXXIX" in the first volume but is presented later in this second-volume-like structure, and the story itself is extensive. The captive, Ruy Perez de Viedma, begins his story, confirming his name and origin from the mountains of Leon. His father, a former soldier, divided his wealth among his three sons, advising them to pursue the Church, trade, or military service. Ruy chose arms, the second brother chose trade in the Indies, and the youngest chose the Church and studies at Salamanca. Ruy gave two-thirds of his inheritance to his father, and his brothers followed suit, leaving their father with ample funds.
Ruy embarked for Italy, joined the Duke of Alva's campaigns in Flanders, and later joined Don John of Austria in the Holy League against the Turks. He became a captain of infantry. At the Battle of Lepanto, he boarded an enemy galley alone when his men couldn't follow, was wounded, and captured by El Uchali, King of Algiers. He was taken to Constantinople, where El Uchali was made general. Ruy witnessed the missed opportunity to capture the Turkish fleet at Navarino and the capture of the galley *Prize*, whose captain was killed by his own slaves.
He was a slave in Constantinople and later in Algiers under the cruel Hassan Aga. He describes the *baños* (prisons) where Christians are kept. One day, on the prison terrace, he saw a white hand waving a reed with a cloth from a window of a wealthy Moorish house. The reed was dropped for him, containing ten gold coins (cianis). Later, a cross made of reeds appeared. He suspected a Christian woman.
Fifteen days later, another reed dropped, containing forty gold crowns and a paper in Arabic with a cross. He confided in a Murcian renegade, who translated the letter. The letter was from a Moorish girl, Zoraida, whose Christian slave had taught her about "Lela Marien" (Virgin Mary). Zoraida, young and beautiful, wanted to go to Christian land and offered her wealth and herself as wife to the Christian who could help her escape.
They wrote a reply, promising to help her and for Ruy to be her husband. Zoraida continued to send money. The renegade, knowing the dangers of ransoming one person at a time, proposed buying a vessel himself, pretending to be a merchant. This plan was agreed upon. They ransomed Ruy and three comrades.
On a Friday, the renegade anchored his vessel near Zoraida's garden. They secured the vessel and then went for Zoraida. The garden gate was open. Zoraida, richly attired and carrying a trunk of gold crowns, met them. Her father, Hadji Morato, awoke and raised an alarm. The renegade and others bound him and covered his mouth. Zoraida, seeing her father, wept but remained with Ruy.
On board, Zoraida begged for her father's release. They agreed to release him on Christian soil. A storm forced them towards Oran. Zoraida kept her head on Ruy's shoulder, praying to Lela Marien. They sighted Spanish land and released the bound Moors, including Hadji Morato. He cursed Zoraida for becoming Christian and abandoning him. Zoraida explained she had to follow Lela Marien.
They were then attacked by French corsairs, who looted them, taking Zoraida's anklets. The captain, showing some pity, gave them a skiff with water and biscuit, and some gold crowns for Zoraida, allowing them to sail to Spain. They landed near Velez Malaga, where a young shepherd, mistaking the Moorish-dressed Zoraida and the renegade for Moors, raised an alarm. They were then met by a group of horsemen, one of whom recognized the young man who had accompanied Ruy as his nephew. All were taken to Velez Malaga, where they returned thanks in the church. Ruy, Zoraida, and the renegade stayed with the nephew's parents. The renegade went to Granada for reconciliation with the Church. Ruy and Zoraida, now with only the French crowns, are traveling to find Ruy's father and brothers.

**Chapter XLII: Which Treats of what Further Took Place in the Inn, and of Several Other Things worth Knowing**
The captive finishes his story, amazing everyone. Don Fernando and others offer him help. A Judge and his beautiful young daughter (Doña Clara) arrive at the inn. Don Quixote welcomes them with a grand speech, mistaking the inn for a castle. The captive recognizes the Judge as his brother, the one who chose the path of letters. The captive (Captain Viedma) confides this to Don Fernando, Cardenio, and the curate, asking for advice on how to reveal himself to his brother. The curate suggests he tell the Judge a story about a captive named Ruy Perez de Viedma. At supper, the curate recounts the captive's story, omitting the current captive's presence. The Judge is deeply moved, recognizing his brother's story and expressing his sorrow and his desire to find him. The curate then reveals Captain Viedma (the captive) to be the Judge's brother, and Zoraida (Ana Felix) his sister-in-law. The brothers embrace emotionally. Don Fernando and Dorothea, and Cardenio and Luscinda are also reunited and embrace. The Judge agrees to take the captain and Zoraida to Seville, where Zoraida will be baptized and their marriage will take place. Don Quixote, observing all, attributes the events to chivalrous "chimeras." Don Quixote offers to guard the "castle."

**Chapter XLIII: Wherein is Related the Pleasant Story of the Muleteer, together with Other Strange Things that Came to Pass in the Inn**
In the early morning, a sweet voice is heard singing in the garden. Dorothea wakes Doña Clara, the Judge's daughter, to listen. Clara is deeply moved and reveals that the singer is Don Luis, a noble youth who lives opposite her father's house in Madrid and is in love with her. He is following her, disguised as a muleteer. Clara is concerned about the disparity in their social status. Dorothea, realizing a new romance, promises to help. Meanwhile, the landlady's daughter and Maritornes decide to play a trick on Don Quixote, who is on watch outside his window. They lower a rope from a hole in the straw-loft. Don Quixote, mistaking it for a signal from a love-smitten lady of the castle, offers his hand. Maritornes ties the rope to his wrist and secures the other end to the door bolt, leaving Don Quixote suspended by his arm.

**Chapter XLIV: In which are Continued the Unheard-of Adventures of the Inn**
Don Quixote's shouts wake the innkeeper. Maritornes unties the rope, and Don Quixote falls. He then mounts Rocinante and declares himself ready to fight anyone who claims he was enchanted. Four travelers arrive, looking for Don Luis (Doña Clara's lover). They find him sleeping with a muleteer. Don Luis's servant tries to persuade him to return home. Cardenio and Dorothea overhear this. Dorothea explains Clara's situation to Cardenio. Don Luis refuses to leave without settling his affairs. The innkeeper gets into a fight with two guests who won't pay. Don Quixote, bound by his promise to the Princess Micomicona, initially refuses to intervene, but then asks for permission from Dorothea. She grants it. Don Quixote draws his sword but hesitates, declaring he cannot fight squires. The brawl escalates. The barber from whom Don Quixote took Mambrino's helmet, arrives and recognizes his pack-saddle on Dapple. A new fight erupts over the helmet and pack-saddle. Don Quixote, believing it's all enchantment, declares the inn to be Agramante's camp and urges them to make peace. The Judge and curate calm the situation. The issue of the pack-saddle and helmet is "settled" (the barber is paid, but Don Quixote's delusion is maintained). Don Luis's servants agree to return home, leaving one to accompany him. An officer recognizes Don Quixote from a warrant for freeing the galley slaves and tries to arrest him. Another brawl starts. Don Quixote furiously fights the officers, still believing in enchantments.

**Chapter XLV: In which the Doubtful Question of Mambrino's Helmet and the Pack-Saddle is Finally Settled, with Other Adventures that Occurred in Truth and Earnest**
Don Quixote's barber (Master Nicholas) backs up Don Quixote's delusion about the basin being Mambrino's helmet. Don Fernando and others play along. The officer insists it's a basin. A Holy Brotherhood officer attempts to arrest Don Quixote for freeing the galley slaves. Don Quixote, in a rage, attacks him. A new brawl erupts. Sancho uses Don Quixote's admission of natural urges to prove he's not enchanted. Don Quixote concedes Sancho's point but still insists he is enchanted. Sancho offers to help him escape the cage. Don Quixote agrees. The curate, canon, and barber, waiting for the cart, let Don Quixote out. Don Quixote stretches and praises Rocinante. The canon, impressed by Don Quixote's lucid moments, tries to persuade him to abandon knight-errantry, suggesting he read true histories instead. Don Quixote vehemently defends the reality of knights-errant, citing historical figures and events. The canon is amazed by Don Quixote's blend of sense and madness. The canon mentions a "Second Part" of Don Quixote's history by another author, which displeases Don Quixote. Sancho complains the author makes him seem like a fool.

**Chapter L: Of the Shrewd Controversy which Don Quixote and the Canon Held, together with Other Incidents**
Don Quixote continues to defend the truth of chivalry books, describing detailed scenes of enchanted castles and damsels. He hopes to become emperor and reward Sancho. Sancho, however, is more concerned with getting his promised county and practical matters. The canon, still trying to dissuade Don Quixote, continues his arguments against the veracity of chivalry. Don Quixote is adamant. They are interrupted by a goatherd who tells a story about Leandra, a beautiful maiden who ran off with a soldier, causing many to become shepherds in despair.

**Chapter LI: Which deals with what the Goatherd told those who were Carrying off Don Quixote**
The goatherd, Eugenio, relates his story: he was in love with Leandra, a beautiful and wealthy farmer's daughter. Another suitor, Anselmo, also courted her. A soldier, Vicente de la Roca, returned to their village, boasting of his exploits. Leandra eloped with Vicente, stealing her father's money and jewels. Vicente abandoned her, but without "robbing her of her honor." Leandra was sent to a convent. Eugenio and Anselmo, heartbroken, became shepherds. Eugenio praises Leandra, while also railing against women's frivolity. Don Quixote offers to rescue Leandra from the convent. Sancho, once again, makes a crude remark and is punished by Don Quixote. They hear a trumpet and see penitents. Don Quixote, believing they are villains abducting a lady, charges them. He is knocked down by a forked stick. Sancho, believing him dead, laments loudly. The curate from Don Quixote's village is recognized by another curate in the procession, and the misunderstanding is cleared. Don Quixote, bruised, agrees to return home in the cart.

**Chapter LII: Of the Quarrel that Don Quixote had with the Goatherd, together with the Rare Adventure of the Penitents, which with an Expenditure of Sweat he brought to a Happy Conclusion**
(This chapter covers the events of the penitents and Don Quixote's subsequent return in the cart, which were also part of the previous summary. I will move on to the next distinct narrative section.)

**Chapter LIII: Of the Troublesome End and Termination Sancho Panza's Government Came To**
Sancho Panza takes possession of his island, Barataria, and is hailed as governor. He is presented with the keys of the town. During his first court session, he cleverly resolves a case about a loan, deducing that the money is hidden in a cane. He resolves another case about a man and a woman, making the woman return the money after she demonstrated her fierce defense of it. He also resolves a tailor's dispute. That night, a letter from the duke warns him of enemies and assassins. Sancho, worried, orders the strict doctor Pedro Recio to be imprisoned (though the order is not carried out). He then receives another letter from Don Quixote, giving him advice on governing. Sancho dictates a reply, complaining of hunger and the doctor's diet. He also describes the young man and woman he found disguised as the opposite sex. Sancho, during his nightly rounds, is ambushed by men who pretend to be attacking the island. They strap two shields to him, making him unable to move, and then trample him. Sancho, terrified and bruised, prays for the island to be lost. He then hears shouts of "victory" and is helped up. Disillusioned, Sancho resigns his governorship, embracing Dapple and declaring he prefers his old freedom. He refuses Doctor Recio's offers, saying he'd rather eat gazpacho than suffer a governor's life. He leaves the island, having gained nothing but experience.

**Chapter LIV: Which Deals with Matters Relating to this History and No Other**
Sancho, on his way back to Don Quixote, meets Ricote, his Morisco neighbor, disguised as a German pilgrim. Ricote explains that he and other Moriscos were expelled from Spain. He has returned secretly to retrieve a buried treasure and find his family. Sancho refuses to help, citing loyalty to the king. Ricote tells him his daughter, Ana Felix, and his brother-in-law went to Algiers. Sancho recounts his governorship. Ricote's daughter, Ana Felix (Zoraida), is rescued from a galley. Don Gregorio, her lover, had disguised himself as a woman to follow her into exile. The captain of the galley is revealed to be Ricote's brother, the Judge. All are joyfully reunited.

**Chapter LV: Of what Befell Sancho on the Road, and Other Things that Cannot be Surpassed**
Sancho, traveling at night, falls into a deep pit with Dapple. He laments his misfortune, comparing it to Don Quixote's better experience in Montesinos's cave. He finds a small opening and enlarges it. Meanwhile, Don Quixote, on his own, discovers the same pit and hears Sancho's cries. He recognizes Sancho's voice. Don Quixote goes to the duke's castle for help. Sancho and Dapple are rescued. Sancho, having resigned his government, complains about the hardships of his brief rule.

**Chapter LVI: Of the Prodigious and Unparalleled Battle that Took Place Between Don Quixote of La Mancha and the Lacquey Tosilos in Defence of the Daughter of Doña Rodriguez**
The duke and duchess are amused by Sancho's account of his government. The day arrives for Don Quixote's battle to defend Doña Rodriguez's daughter against the farmer's son (now replaced by the lacquey Tosilos). The duke orders the lance heads removed for safety. Tosilos, however, falls in love with Doña Rodriguez's daughter at first sight and declares himself vanquished, offering to marry her. Don Quixote accepts this as a victory. Doña Rodriguez and her daughter are furious, realizing Tosilos is a lacquey and that they have been tricked. Don Quixote believes it's another enchantment. The duke suggests a fortnight's delay to see if Tosilos transforms back. Tosilos and the daughter are contented to marry.

**Chapter LVII: Which Treats of how Don Quixote took Leave of the Duke, and of what Followed with the Witty and Impudent Altisidora, one of the Duchess's Damsels**
Don Quixote resolves to leave the castle, feeling his indolence is unbecoming. Sancho receives Teresa's letters and money from the majordomo. Altisidora, still feigning love, sings a lament for Don Quixote, accusing him of ingratitude and theft of her kerchiefs and garters. Sancho admits to having the kerchiefs. Don Quixote rejects Altisidora again, reaffirming his loyalty to Dulcinea. He attributes Altisidora's "love" to idleness. Don Quixote and Sancho depart for Saragossa.

**Chapter LVIII: Which Tells how Adventures Came Crowding on Don Quixote in such Numbers that they gave one another no Breathing-time**
Don Quixote and Sancho travel through open country. Don Quixote praises freedom. Sancho reveals the 200 crowns from the majordomo. They encounter men with religious images for a retablo. Don Quixote identifies the images as saints, comparing them to knights-errant. He is pleased by this "omen." Sancho is amazed by his master's knowledge. They are then trampled by a drove of bulls. Don Quixote attributes it to enchanters. He and Sancho continue their journey, disheartened.

**Chapter LIX: Wherein is Related the Strange Thing, which may be Regarded as an Adventure, that Happened Don Quixote**
Don Quixote and Sancho rest by a spring. Don Quixote, depressed by his recent defeat by the bulls, expresses a desire to die. Sancho comforts him, urging him to eat and sleep. Don Quixote asks Sancho to give himself more lashes for Dulcinea's disenchantment. Sancho agrees for double pay. They camp. Don Quixote is again kept awake by thoughts. Sancho sleeps. Don Quixote, composing a madrigal, is interrupted by a herd of pigs that tramples them. Don Quixote attributes this to enchanters. They are then ambushed by armed men who silently take them captive and transport them to the duke's castle.

**Chapter LX: Of what Happened Don Quixote on his Way to Barcelona**
At the castle, Don Quixote and Sancho are led into a torchlit courtyard where a catafalque holds the "dead" body of Altisidora. Figures resembling kings (Minos and Rhadamanthus) and Merlin are present. Sancho is dressed in a flaming robe and a mitre. Merlin announces that Altisidora's revival depends on Sancho receiving 24 smacks, 12 pinches, and 6 pin thrusts. Sancho vehemently protests, but Don Quixote urges him to comply. Sancho is tormented by the duennas. Altisidora "revives," confirming the disenchantment. Sancho is given six smocks as a reward. Altisidora, now "alive," scolds Don Quixote for his insensibility. Don Quixote and Sancho return to their room.

**Chapter LXI: Of what Happened Don Quixote on Entering Barcelona, together with Other Matters that Partake of the True rather than of the Ingenious**
Don Quixote and Sancho leave the duke's castle, heading for Barcelona to avoid the jousts in Saragossa (mentioned in the "new" history). Don Quixote encounters Roque Guinart, a highwayman, who returns Sancho's stolen kerchiefs. Roque writes a letter to a friend in Barcelona announcing Don Quixote's arrival. Upon entering Barcelona, Don Quixote and Sancho are greeted by a large procession led by Don Antonio Moreno, who recognizes Don Quixote from his printed history. Boys playing a prank put burrs under Rocinante's and Dapple's tails, causing them to buck and throw their riders. Don Quixote is embarrassed.

**Chapter LXII: Which Deals with the Adventure of the Enchanted Head, together with Other Trivial Matters which Cannot be Left Untold**
Don Quixote is welcomed into Don Antonio Moreno's house. Don Antonio, a witty gentleman, plans new tricks. He displays Don Quixote on a balcony in street clothes. Don Quixote entertains guests at dinner. Don Antonio shows Don Quixote a bronze "enchanted head" that answers questions (a clever mechanical trick). Don Quixote and others ask questions. The head gives general answers. Sancho asks about future governorships and seeing his family, receiving vague but positive replies. The trick is later revealed by Cide Hamete. Don Quixote visits a printing office and discovers a "Second Part of Don Quixote" by an Aragonese author. He is displeased by its inaccuracies. Don Antonio takes Don Quixote to see the galleys.

**Chapter LXIII: Of the Mishap that Befell Sancho Panza through the Visit to the Galleys, and the Strange Adventure of the Fair Morisco**
Don Quixote and Sancho visit the galleys. Don Quixote is given a grand reception. Sancho is subjected to a "flying" ceremony, being passed hand-to-hand by the rowers. Don Quixote suggests Sancho take lashes among the rowers to disenchant Dulcinea. A brigantine is sighted. The galleys pursue and capture it. The general intends to hang the rais (captain) and crew. The rais reveals himself to be a Christian woman, Ana Felix (Zoraida), whose lover, Don Gregorio, had disguised himself as a woman to accompany her into exile in Algiers. She tells her story of being a Morisco Christian, her abduction, and Don Gregorio's plight. Ricote (Ana Felix's father) is present, disguised as a pilgrim, and reveals himself. Ana Felix and Ricote are joyfully reunited with the Judge (Ricote's brother). Don Gregorio is still captive in Algiers. Ricote offers money for his rescue. A renegade offers to go.

**Chapter LXIV: Treating of the Adventure which gave Don Quixote more Unhappiness than all that had hitherto Befallen him**
Don Quixote advises a direct rescue of Don Gregorio in Barbary, but Don Antonio and the viceroy decide to trust the renegade. As Don Quixote is walking on the beach, he is challenged by the "Knight of the White Moon." The knight demands Don Quixote acknowledge his lady's beauty is superior to Dulcinea's, or face combat. If Don Quixote loses, he must return home and cease knight-errantry for a year. Don Quixote accepts. They joust. The Knight of the White Moon unhorses Don Quixote. Don Quixote, defeated, declares Dulcinea the fairest and agrees to the terms of retirement. The Knight of the White Moon is revealed to be Samson Carrasco, who undertook this to force Don Quixote home. Sancho is heartbroken by his master's defeat. Don Gregorio is eventually rescued. Ricote, Ana Felix, and Don Gregorio are reunited. Don Antonio takes them to the capital to try and secure their stay in Spain. Don Quixote and Sancho prepare to return home.

**Chapter LXV: Wherein is Made Known who the Knight of the White Moon was; likewise Don Gregorio's Release, and Other Events**
(This chapter provides the backstory of Samson Carrasco's disguise as the Knight of the White Moon, which was already summarized above. It also details Don Gregorio's rescue and the reunions, which were also previously covered.)

**Chapter LXVI: Which Treats of what he who Reads will see, or what he who has it Read to him will Hear**
Don Quixote, defeated, laments his loss of glory. Sancho consoles him. Don Quixote acknowledges his recklessness and resolves to keep his word to retire for a year. He plans to become a shepherd. They encounter a group of peasants who ask Don Quixote to judge a dispute. Sancho, feeling authoritative, intervenes and makes a droll judgment. They continue their journey.

**Chapter LXVII: Of the Resolution Don Quixote Formed to Turn Shepherd and Take to a Life in the Fields while the Year for which he had Given his Word was Running its Course; with other Events truly Delectable and Happy**
Don Quixote, still haunted by his defeat and Altisidora's "love," proposes to Sancho that they become shepherds for a year, using pastoral names. Sancho enthusiastically agrees, suggesting other friends join them and plans to name his wife Teresona. They discuss their pastoral instruments and the dangers of love in the fields. Don Quixote chides Sancho for his proverbs, but Sancho argues he uses them aptly.

**Chapter LXVIII: Of the Bristly Adventure that Befell Don Quixote**
Don Quixote, unable to sleep, urges Sancho to give himself more lashes for Dulcinea. Sancho refuses, praising sleep. A herd of pigs tramples them. Don Quixote attributes this to enchanters, seeing it as punishment. Sancho blames it on their bad luck. Don Quixote, still thinking of his pastoral plan, composes a madrigal. They are ambushed by armed men, who silently take them captive and bring them back to the duke's castle. This is revealed to be another trick.

**Chapter LXIX: Of the Strangest and Most Extraordinary Adventure that Befell Don Quixote in the Whole Course of this Great History**
Don Quixote and Sancho are brought into the castle courtyard, where Altisidora lies on a catafalque, seemingly dead. A mock ceremony is performed: Sancho is dressed in a flaming robe and mitre, and Merlin (the majordomo) demands lashes, pinches, and pin thrusts to revive Altisidora. Sancho protests loudly, but Don Quixote urges him to submit. Sancho is tormented by duennas. Altisidora "revives." She gives Sancho six smocks. Don Quixote and Sancho are returned to their room.

**Chapter LXX: Which Follows Sixty-nine and Deals with Matters Indispensable for the Clear Comprehension of this History**
Don Quixote, still believing in enchantments, discusses Altisidora's "death" and Sancho's role in her "resurrection." Sancho, tired of the tricks, wants to sleep. The chapter reveals that Samson Carrasco, still determined to cure Don Quixote, went to the duke's castle and revealed his prior attempt as the Knight of the Mirrors. The duke and duchess, finding Don Quixote and Sancho amusing, then orchestrated the elaborate "enchantment" scenarios. Altisidora, continuing the joke, enters Don Quixote's room, feigning love again, but Don Quixote rejects her, reiterating his fidelity to Dulcinea.

**Chapter LXXI: Of what Passed between Don Quixote and his Squire Sancho on the Way to their Village**
Don Quixote and Sancho leave the duke's castle. Sancho complains about not receiving the promised smocks from Altisidora. Don Quixote agrees to pay Sancho for his lashes (half a real per lash). Sancho enthusiastically agrees, calculating the total. That night, Sancho begins to flog himself with a halter, but mostly hits trees. Don Quixote, fearing for Sancho's life and his own objective, stops him after a thousand lashes. They continue their journey. They stop at an inn, which Don Quixote now recognizes as an inn, not a castle. In a neighboring room, two gentlemen are reading a "Second Part of Don Quixote" by a new author, which they criticize. Don Quixote, hearing this, denounces the false history and asserts his true identity. The gentlemen come to his room and confirm he is the genuine Don Quixote. Sancho also claims to be the true Sancho Panza. Don Quixote refuses to read the false history. They decide to go to Barcelona instead of Saragossa, to expose the impostor.

**Chapter LXXII: Of how Don Quixote and Sancho Reached their Village**
Don Quixote and Sancho encounter Don Álvaro Tarfe, a character from the false "Second Part" of Don Quixote. Don Álvaro states he knows the "other" Don Quixote and Sancho. Don Quixote and Sancho convince him that they are the true figures, and that the other history is false. Don Álvaro agrees to make a legal declaration before the village alcalde that he never knew this Don Quixote and Sancho before, and that they are not the characters from the false book. This declaration is made. Don Quixote and Sancho continue towards their village. Sancho finishes his lashes, to Don Quixote's great joy.

**Chapter LXXIII: Of the Omens Don Quixote had as he Entered his own Village, and other Incidents that Embellish and give a Colour to this Great History**
At the village entrance, Don Quixote encounters omens which he interprets negatively (a boy's words about never seeing something again, a hare chased by greyhounds). Sancho, however, interprets them positively. They meet the curate and bachelor Carrasco. Sancho is still wearing the flaming robe and Dapple the mitre from the castle tricks. Don Quixote informs them of his defeat and his year-long retirement, proposing they all become shepherds. The curate and bachelor agree, hoping to cure his madness. The housekeeper and niece lament his continued delusions, urging him to stay home.

**Chapter LXXIV: Of how Don Quixote Fell Sick, and of the Will he Made, and how he Died**
Don Quixote falls ill with a fever, remaining in bed for six days. His friends and family try to cheer him, but the doctor confirms he is dying. After a long sleep, Don Quixote wakes up, completely lucid. He renounces books of chivalry, declaring that his reason is restored and he is no longer Don Quixote but Alonso Quixano the Good. His friends and family are amazed and relieved. He makes his will, leaving his property to his niece with the condition that she not marry anyone who knows about books of chivalry. He forgives Sancho, acknowledging their adventures were based on his madness, and leaves him money as compensation for his services. Sancho weeps, begging him not to die, and suggests they still become shepherds. Don Quixote dies peacefully in his bed, having renounced chivalry. The notary attests to his natural death, preventing further false histories. Cide Hamete concludes the history, declaring Don Quixote's story has served to discredit all other books of chivalry.

At the Borgo Pass, a calèche with four coal-black horses and a tall, strong driver with a long brown beard and red eyes meets him. The driver's handshake is of prodigious strength. The calèche takes a circuitous route, and Harker notices the driver can control packs of howling wolves with a silent gesture. They arrive at a vast, ruined castle.

Inside the castle, Harker is greeted by Count Dracula, a tall old man with a long white moustache, dressed in black, with sharp white teeth and pointed ears. His handshake is cold and incredibly strong, leading Harker to suspect he might be the same man as the driver. The Count insists on carrying Harker's luggage and serves him supper, but says he has already dined. Harker gives the Count a sealed letter from his employer, Mr. Hawkins, regarding the purchase of a London estate. Harker notes the Count's unusual physiognomy and the fact he has hair in the center of his palms. The Count's breath causes Harker nausea. That night, the Count's eyes gleam when he hears wolves howl, calling them "children of the night." He dismisses Harker to bed, stating he will be away until the afternoon.

On **May 7**, Harker wakes to find a cold breakfast and a note from "D." He notices the castle has no mirrors and no servants, only the howling of wolves. He discovers a library but other doors are locked. The Count returns and speaks of his desire to move to London to learn English customs and achieve mastery there. He asks Harker to stay a month to help him refine his English. He explains that on a certain night (St. George's Eve, May 4th), blue flames appear over concealed treasure, but peasants are too cowardly to seek it. The Count lunges at Harker's throat but recoils when his hand touches the crucifix Harker wears. The Count then seizes Harker's shaving mirror and throws it out the window, shattering it, calling it a "foul bauble of man's vanity." Harker then discovers all exit doors from his part of the castle are locked, realizing he is a prisoner.

Later, Harker deduces that the Count himself must be the calèche driver, explaining his control over the wolves. He resolves to keep his fears hidden. He has a long conversation with the Count about Transylvanian history and the Count's Szekely ancestors, who claim descent from Attila.
