Realizing he's trapped, he decides to climb the castle wall, preferring death by falling to remaining with the "awful women."

The narrative shifts to other characters. Mina Murray writes to Lucy Westenra on **May 9**, mentioning Jonathan's expected return. Lucy writes to Mina, confessing her love for Arthur Holmwood and mentioning proposals from Dr. John Seward (a doctor at a lunatic asylum) and Quincey P. Morris (an American). Lucy accepts Arthur's proposal.

Dr. Seward's diary entries detail his patient, R. M. Renfield, a "zoöphagous maniac" who eats flies, spiders, and birds, believing he absorbs their lives. On **August 20**, Renfield becomes quiet from moonrise to sunrise, saying "The Master is at hand." On **August 23**, Renfield escapes to the chapel at Carfax, worshipping an unseen "Master." He fights fiercely when restrained.

Lucy's health deteriorates. On **August 24**, she feels weak, pale, and has a painful throat, remembering bad dreams. Arthur asks Dr. Seward to examine her. Seward finds her anemic-looking with no apparent disease and consults his old master, Professor Van Helsing.

On **September 7**, Van Helsing examines Lucy, who is "ghastly, chalkily pale." He determines she needs a blood transfusion. Arthur, her fiancé, provides blood. Van Helsing notices a small red mark on Lucy's throat. Mrs. Westenra, Lucy's mother, who has heart disease, removes the garlic flowers Van Helsing had placed in Lucy's room, believing the room was stuffy. Van Helsing is distraught, crying "God! God! God!" He performs another transfusion, this time with his own blood, and warns Mrs. Westenra not to touch the "medicinal" flowers again.

On **September 17**, Lucy believes she is recovering, but is sleepwalking again. That night, she records in a memorandum that she was woken by flapping at her window. A "great, gaunt grey wolf" broke the window. Her mother, startled, tore off Lucy's garlic wreath. Her mother then suffered a "horrible gurgling in her throat" and died. Lucy felt a "spell" and saw myriad specks blowing in. She later found the maids drugged with laudanum. She is alone with her dead mother and the wolf howls outside.

On **September 18**, Seward and Van Helsing find Mrs. Westenra dead and Lucy near death. The garlic flowers are on Mrs. Westenra's body, and Lucy's throat wounds are "horribly white and mangled." Arthur and Quincey Morris provide blood for more transfusions. Van Helsing finds Lucy's memorandum. On **September 19**, Lucy's condition worsens. Her teeth appear longer and sharper. She asks Arthur to kiss her, but Van Helsing forcibly pulls him away, saying "Not for your life!" A spasm of rage crosses Lucy's face. She then dies. Van Helsing declares, "It is only the beginning!"

Van Helsing explains that Lucy is "Un-Dead." He reveals his intention to cut off her head and stake her heart to save her soul. He temporarily seals her tomb with consecrated Host. On **September 25**, newspaper reports describe "The Hampstead Horror": children are being found with punctured throats, claiming they were lured away by a "bloofer lady."

On **September 26**, Jonathan Harker sees the Count in Piccadilly, noting he looks younger. Jonathan recognizes him as "the man himself!" and is terrified. Mina reads Jonathan's journal and realizes the terrible truth. Van Helsing explains to Seward that Lucy became "Un-Dead" after being bitten by a vampire. He proves this by taking Seward to Lucy's empty coffin at night, then later finds her body returned, but with crimson lips and sharper teeth. That same night, they find Lucy (as the "bloofer lady") with a child in the churchyard. Van Helsing restrains her with a crucifix. He explains that Lucy must be truly killed to free her soul.

On **September 29**, Arthur, Quincey, and Seward join Van Helsing in Lucy's tomb. Van Helsing explains that Un-Dead creatures are immortal and multiply by preying on the living. He states that if Arthur had been bitten or kissed by the Un-Dead Lucy, he too would have become a _nosferatu_. He explains that driving a stake through her heart, cutting off her head, and filling her mouth with garlic will set her soul free. Arthur, with immense courage and sorrow, performs the ritual. Lucy's body writhes and screeches, but then transforms into her former beautiful, peaceful self and crumbles to dust. The men are relieved. They proceed to cut off her head, fill her mouth with garlic, and reseal her coffin. Van Helsing then dedicates them to finding and destroying the author of their sorrow.

Jonathan Harker, having investigated the delivery of the Count's boxes, discovers there were 50 boxes of "common earth" shipped from Varna to Whitby, and then delivered to Carfax. He traces 9 of these boxes to a house in Piccadilly. He learns the Count carried them himself and appeared younger. Renfield, Seward's patient, experiences mood swings linked to the Count's proximity. He speaks of the Count as his "Master" and of gaining "life" without "souls."

On **October 1**, the group (Van Helsing, Seward, Harker, Lord Godalming, Quincey Morris, and Mina) meets. Van Helsing reveals the Count's abilities: strength of twenty men, no reflection, no shadow, transformation into wolf or bat, control of elements (fog, storm, thunder), command over animals (rats, owls, bats, foxes, wolves), ability to grow small or vanish, and entry into anywhere he's invited. His power ceases at daybreak, and he can only change form at noon, sunrise, or sunset. He can't cross running water except at slack or flood tide. He is repelled by garlic and crucifixes. A wild rose branch on his coffin keeps him from moving; a sacred bullet or a stake through the heart kills him; cutting off his head brings rest. Van Helsing identifies the Count as Voivode Dracula, a historical figure known for cunning and bravery.

They decide to sterilize the Count's lairs by placing consecrated Host in his earth-boxes. They visit Carfax and find only 29 of the 50 boxes remain. They encounter a swarm of rats, which are driven away by Lord Godalming's terriers. They sterilize the remaining boxes. They then go to the Piccadilly house, where they find 8 of the 9 boxes and sterilize them, finding only one missing. The Count appears, having escaped their trap, and leaps from the window, calling out, "My revenge is just begun!"

The group returns to Seward's house. Mina expresses pity for the Count, believing he deserves "spiritual immortality" if his "worser part" is destroyed. Jonathan is enraged, but Mina tells him to be merciful, reminding him that she too may someday need such pity.

On **October 3**, Renfield, beaten and with a broken back and skull fracture, is found in his room. Before he dies, he reveals that the Count visited him in a mist, offering him "lives" (thousands of rats, then dogs, then cats) if he would worship him. Renfield, tempted, invited the Count in. Later, the Count took life from Mina. Renfield, realizing this, fought the Count, but his strength failed.

The group rushes to Mina and Jonathan's room. They find Jonathan in a stupor. The Count is kneeling on the bed beside Mina, forcing her face into an open wound on his breast, making her drink his blood. Her white nightdress is smeared with blood, and a red scar is on her forehead. The men recoil, holding up crucifixes and Sacred Wafer. The Count cringes and disappears into a faint vapor. Mina awakens, horrified, realizing she is "unclean" and now "his worst enemy." The Count's act of forcing her to drink his blood has created a "terrible baptism of blood," giving him power over her, but also giving her a psychic link to him. Mina reveals that the Count mocked them, stating he has commanded nations for centuries and was "countermining" them while they "played wits" against him.

The group decides that Mina must be in full confidence. She, brave but despairing, asks them to kill her if she becomes a vampire, and they all swear to do so, including Jonathan. She also asks them to read the Burial Service over her. Mina then reveals that the Count is escaping by ship. Van Helsing deduces he is returning to Transylvania via the Danube mouth, probably on the _Czarina Catherine_, which left the Thames yesterday. They plan to travel overland to Varna (or Galatz) to intercept him. Jonathan, Arthur, and Quincey will pursue him by land and water. Van Helsing will take Mina to the Borgo Pass. Mina can be hypnotized at sunrise and sunset to reveal the Count's location and movements.

On **October 28**, a telegram confirms the _Czarina Catherine_ has arrived at Galatz. Mina, surprisingly, knows the train schedules and helps plan their pursuit. Van Helsing explains that the Count, in his "child-brain," thinks he has cut Mina off from his knowledge, but the "baptism of blood" gives Mina a unique link to him, allowing her to sense his actions, especially at sunrise and sunset.

The group travels to Galatz. On **October 29**, Mina is hypnotized. She reports hearing "men's voices calling," "roll and creak of oars," and "tramping of feet overhead," indicating the Count has left the ship and is on a river vessel. She stops speaking at sunrise. On **October 30**, Mina is again hypnotized. She describes "water swirling," "creaking of wood," and "cattle low far off," confirming the Count is on an open boat on a river, likely upstream. The ship's captain recounts a phenomenally quick journey aided by a persistent fog, and that a "queer lookin' old man" (the Count) had his box taken off before sunrise by an agent named Petrof Skinsky. Skinsky is later found murdered, his throat torn open.

Mina, examining maps, deduces the Count is traveling up the Sereth or Pruth rivers, likely towards the Bistritza, which loops closest to his castle near the Borgo Pass. The group splits: Lord Godalming and Jonathan Harker take a steam launch up the river. Dr. Seward and Quincey Morris ride along the river banks. Van Helsing takes Mina by carriage to the Borgo Pass, intending to confront the Count at his castle.

On **November 4**, Van Helsing, with Mina, arrives at the Borgo Pass. Mina, guided by a "new guiding power," points to a specific road to the castle. Mina falls into a deep sleep that Van Helsing cannot break, but at sunset, she wakes, looking healthy and bright, refusing to eat. Van Helsing, suspicious, draws a circle of consecrated Host around her. Horses scream as the three Un-Dead women from the castle appear outside the circle, circling and calling Mina to "Come, sister." Mina, however, shows terror and repulsion. Van Helsing, realizing the red scar on Mina's forehead is the mark of the vampire's power, uses the Host to drive the women away. They melt into mist and snow. The horses are found dead. Van Helsing then proceeds to Dracula's castle, breaking doors, and finds the three women in their tombs. He performs the ritual of staking and decapitation on them, and their bodies crumble to dust. He places Host in Dracula's tomb, banishing him from it forever. He then returns to Mina.

On **November 6**, Mina and Van Helsing watch from a rocky hollow near the castle. They see a group of mounted Szgany with a leiter-wagon carrying a great square chest, hurrying towards the castle. Simultaneously, Dr. Seward and Quincey Morris, and then Lord Godalming and Jonathan Harker, converge on the wagon from different directions. The sun is setting. Jonathan and Quincey leap onto the wagon and furiously attack the chest. Quincey is wounded by a gypsy's knife, bleeding heavily. Jonathan's great knife shears through the Count's throat, and Quincey's bowie knife plunges into his heart. The Count's body crumbles to dust, a look of peace on his face. Quincey Morris, dying, points to Mina, whose red scar on her forehead has vanished. He says, "The snow is not more stainless than her forehead! The curse has passed away!" He dies with a smile. The gypsies flee, and the wolves follow them. The Castle of Dracula stands outlined against the red sky.

The story begins with a series of letters from Robert Walton, an English explorer, to his sister, Mrs. Saville, in England. Walton is on an expedition to the North Pole, driven by an ardent desire to discover a new passage, ascertain the secret of the magnet, and explore unknown lands. He recounts his lifelong passion for discovery, his training, and his determination, despite his sister's forebodings and his own fluctuating hopes.

From Archangel, Walton writes about hiring a ship and crew. He expresses a profound loneliness and a longing for a true friend, someone to share his triumphs and support him in despair, noting his self-education and lack of a cultivated companion. He describes his brave but uneducated lieutenant and his gentle, kind-hearted master, recounting an anecdote of the master's selfless love. Walton reaffirms his resolve for the perilous voyage, despite the severe winter.

Weeks later, Walton sends a brief letter reporting his safe progress and high spirits, sailing at a high latitude.

His next letter details a "strange accident." His ship becomes surrounded by ice and thick fog. When the mist clears, they observe a gigantic man in a sledge, drawn by dogs, speeding northward across the ice. The next morning, they discover another sledge on a large ice fragment, containing a near-dead European man. This stranger, who speaks English with a foreign accent, refuses to board until he learns their destination. Upon hearing they are bound for the northern pole, he consents. Walton describes the stranger's emaciated condition and profound grief, noting his eyes fluctuate between wildness and benevolence. The stranger reveals he is "To seek one who fled from me," and confirms his quarry traveled in a similar sledge. This convinces Walton that the gigantic figure they saw earlier was the one the stranger pursued. The stranger, eager to continue his pursuit, is too weak to go on deck. Walton becomes deeply sympathetic, feeling an affection for him "as a brother."

The stranger, identified as Frankenstein, gradually recovers and spends his time watching for the other sledge. He discusses Walton's expedition, becoming deeply agitated when Walton speaks of sacrificing his life for knowledge. Frankenstein warns Walton against pursuing such "madness" and offers to tell his own "tale" as a cautionary example. After much persuasion, Frankenstein agrees to begin his narrative the following day, and Walton resolves to record it.

Frankenstein begins his story, identifying himself as a Genevese from a distinguished family. He recounts his father's honorable life and his marriage to Caroline Beaufort, a woman his father rescued from poverty. Victor was their eldest child, born in Naples, and cherished. When he was five, his mother adopted Elizabeth Lavenza, a beautiful orphan of Milanese nobility, intending her as a "pretty present" for Victor, who considered her "mine—mine to protect, love, and cherish." They grew up together, with Elizabeth delighting in poetry and nature, while Victor pursued the "hidden laws of nature." He formed a close friendship with Henry Clerval, a boy of singular talent and fancy, who loved chivalry and literature.

Victor's early studies were focused on the ancient alchemists like Cornelius Agrippa. His father dismissed these as "sad trash," but Victor persisted. At fifteen, a violent thunderstorm destroyed an oak tree, sparking his interest in electricity and galvanism. He then abandoned his alchemical studies, considering them "exploded systems," and turned to mathematics.

At seventeen, Victor prepares to attend the University of Ingolstadt. Before his departure, Elizabeth contracts scarlet fever. His mother nurses her back to health but contracts the illness herself and dies. On her deathbed, she expresses her wish for Victor and Elizabeth to marry and for Elizabeth to care for her younger children. Victor's departure is delayed by mourning. Clerval's father prevents him from joining Victor at the university. Victor travels alone to Ingolstadt, feeling lonely but eager for knowledge. He meets M. Krempe, a gruff natural philosophy professor who scoffs at his past studies. However, M. Waldman, a chemistry professor, inspires Victor with his lecture on modern science, which, while dismissing alchemy's "chimerical" goals, promises "almost unlimited powers." This lecture rekindles Victor's scientific passion, focusing it on chemistry and natural philosophy.

For two years, Victor dedicates himself entirely to these studies, neglecting his family. His progress is rapid, astonishing his peers and professors. He becomes fascinated by the "principle of life," delving into physiology, anatomy, and the processes of decay and corruption in the human body, spending time in charnel-houses. Through intense labor, he discovers the "cause of generation and life" and gains the ability to "bestow animation upon lifeless matter." He initially considers creating a being like himself but, due to the difficulty of working with minute parts, decides to make it of gigantic stature (about eight feet tall). He collects materials from "charnel-houses" and "slaughter-house[s]," working in a solitary workshop. This gruesome work isolates him, causes his health to decline, and fills him with nervousness and guilt.

On a "dreary night of November," Victor successfully animates his creation. The creature opens its "dull yellow eye" and breathes. Despite having carefully chosen its features, Victor is filled with "breathless horror and disgust" at its hideous appearance—yellow skin, watery eyes, shrivelled complexion, and black lips. He flees the room. He attempts to sleep but is tormented by nightmares of Elizabeth turning into his dead mother. He wakes to find the creature standing over his bed, its hand outstretched. Victor escapes, spending the night agitated in the courtyard.

The next morning, he encounters Henry Clerval, who has arrived to study at Ingolstadt. Overjoyed at seeing his friend, Victor's spirits lift, and he momentarily forgets his horror. Clerval notes Victor's ill appearance. Fearing Clerval might see the monster, Victor rushes to his apartment, finds it empty, and rejoices that the creature has fled. Overcome by extreme sensitivity, he suffers a nervous fever for several months, during which Clerval diligently nurses him, concealing the true extent of his illness from Victor's family. Victor raves incoherently during his delirium, implicitly confessing his creation and the monster's deeds. Clerval, though perplexed, attributes it to his friend's disturbed imagination.

Victor slowly recovers, and Clerval gives him a letter from Elizabeth, who expresses concern for his long silence and reports on their family. She mentions their younger brother, William, and the return of Justine Moritz, a beloved servant who had lived with the family. Victor writes back immediately. Upon recovery, he tries to resume normal life, but the sight of scientific instruments renews his agony. He studies Oriental languages with Clerval, seeking solace. During their travels through England and Scotland, Victor finds some temporary relief in nature and Clerval's company but remains haunted by his secret and the monster's existence.

He receives a letter from his father informing him that William has been murdered, strangled, with finger marks on his neck, and a valuable miniature of Victor's mother, which Elizabeth had given William, is missing. His father urges Victor to return to console Elizabeth, who blames herself. Victor, traveling back to Geneva, spots the gigantic monster during a thunderstorm near the murder scene and is instantly convinced the creature is William's murderer. He considers revealing this but realizes his story would be dismissed as madness. Upon arriving home, his brother Ernest tells him that Justine Moritz has been accused of the murder. Victor is horrified, knowing Justine is innocent.

At the trial, Justine maintains her innocence, explaining she was locked out of the city gates searching for William and spent the night in a barn. She cannot explain how the miniature came to be in her pocket. Elizabeth passionately defends Justine's character, but the circumstantial evidence, especially the miniature, and Justine's initial confusion, lead to her condemnation. Overwhelmed by fear of being thought mad, Victor remains silent. Justine later confesses under pressure from her confessor, who threatened her with excommunication. She tells Victor and Elizabeth that her confession was a lie, made to gain absolution, but now feels more guilt for it. Justine is executed the next day. Victor is consumed by guilt and remorse, believing himself the "true murderer" and the cause of William's and Justine's deaths, as well as his family's grief.

Overwhelmed, Victor retreats to solitude, contemplating suicide but restrained by his duty to his remaining family and his desire for revenge against the monster. His father and Elizabeth are also deeply saddened. Elizabeth expresses her disillusionment with mankind, lamenting William's and Justine's deaths and the murderer's escape. Victor, tormented, travels to the Alpine valley of Chamounix.

In Chamounix, Victor confronts the monster on a glacier. The monster, with "superhuman speed," approaches. Victor, filled with rage, curses him as "devil" and "vile insect" and tries to attack him. The monster easily evades him and proposes a discussion, reminding Victor that as his creator, Victor owes him happiness. The monster explains that his malice stems from the misery of his solitude and rejection. He declares, "I was benevolent and good; misery made me a fiend. Make me happy, and I shall again be virtuous." He demands Victor create a female companion for him, promising that they will then retreat to the "vast wilds of South America" and never trouble mankind again. Victor initially refuses, fearing a race of devils, but the monster's arguments of justice, his threats of continued vengeance against Victor's remaining friends, and Victor's sense of duty compel him to agree, on the condition that the monster swears to leave Europe forever. The monster swears and departs.

Victor returns to Geneva, struggling to begin his new, abhorrent task. His health, which had partially recovered, begins to decline again. His father notices his melancholy and suggests he marry Elizabeth immediately, fearing Victor secretly loves another or feels bound by an unwanted promise to Elizabeth. Victor assures him of his love for Elizabeth and agrees to the marriage. To gain time and materials for his work, Victor tells his father he wishes to travel to England to consult philosophers. His father agrees, hoping the change of scene will restore him, and arranges for Clerval to accompany him.

Victor and Clerval travel through England, visiting London, Windsor, Oxford, and the Lake District. Victor finds little joy, constantly preoccupied with his dreadful task and haunted by the monster's threat, "I will be with you on your wedding-night." He secretly collects materials. After months, they travel to Scotland. In Perth, Victor tells Clerval he wishes to travel alone for a month or two, so he can proceed to a remote Orkney Island, where he intends to complete the female creature in solitude.

On the desolate island, Victor works on the second creature, but this time, without the "enthusiastic frenzy" of his first creation, he finds the process "horrible and irksome," often sickening at the work. As the female is nearly complete, he reflects on the potential consequences: she might be even more malignant, refuse to comply with the monster's compact, or they might hate each other, leading to greater destruction, perhaps even a "race of devils." He realizes the "wickedness of my promise" and shudders at the thought of sacrificing the human race for his own peace. He looks up and sees the monster at the window, watching him. Horrified by the monster's malicious gaze, Victor tears the half-finished female creature to pieces. The monster, howling in "devilish despair and revenge," withdraws.

Victor vows never to resume his work. Later that night, the monster enters his room. He confronts Victor, accusing him of breaking his promise and recounting his difficult journey following Victor. Victor firmly refuses to create a companion, citing the monster's wickedness. The monster declares that if he cannot inspire love, he will inspire fear, and reiterates his threat: "I will be with you on your wedding-night." He then vanishes.

Victor is tormented by this threat, believing it means his own death. The next morning, he packs the remains of the second creature with stones and, at sea, casts them into the ocean. A storm arises, and he is driven far off course, eventually landing in Ireland. There, he is immediately accused of murder.

Brought before Magistrate Kirwin, Victor hears testimony about a strangled body found on the beach, with finger marks on its neck. He is greatly agitated, remembering William. A witness claims to have seen a boat similar to Victor's near the shore. Victor is taken to view the body and is horrified to discover it is Henry Clerval. He collapses in convulsions, exclaiming his "murderous machinations" have claimed another victim. He falls into a nervous fever for two months, during which he raves about being the murderer of William, Justine, and Clerval. Magistrate Kirwin, understanding French, overhears these ravings but kindly ensures Victor receives care.

Upon recovery, Victor is imprisoned. Mr. Kirwin informs him that his family is safe and his father is coming. Victor, in a moment of delirium, mistakes his father for the monster and cries out in agony. His father arrives, comforting him. Victor remains deeply melancholic, haunted by Clerval's image and the sense of a dreadful destiny. He is liberated from prison after it is proven he was on the Orkney Islands at the time of Clerval's murder. He feels no joy in freedom, only "frightful darkness." His father attempts to cheer him, but Victor is consumed by despair and periodically attempts suicide. He is eventually deemed mad and confined for months.

Upon regaining his reason, Victor is again driven by revenge. He resolves to return to Geneva to protect his family and hunt the monster. He relates his story to a criminal judge, asking for the monster's apprehension. The judge is incredulous, doubting the monster's existence and the feasibility of pursuit. Victor, enraged, vows to pursue and destroy the monster himself.

Victor leaves Geneva forever, beginning a long pursuit across Europe and into the wilds of Tartary and Russia. He is sustained only by revenge, enduring extreme hardships. The monster, at times, leaves clues, guiding Victor, and sometimes even provides food, fearing Victor might die and end their chase. In his sleep, Victor finds solace, dreaming of his loved ones. The monster leaves mocking inscriptions, urging Victor further north into the "everlasting ices."

Victor acquires a sledge and dogs, gaining on the monster. He tracks him to a hamlet on the seashore, where villagers report a "gigantic monster" (the fiend) stole their food and fled across the frozen sea. Victor, despite the extreme cold, pursues him onto the ice. After weeks of suffering, he sights the monster's sledge. He gains on him, but a violent storm breaks up the ice, creating an impassable sea between them. Victor is left adrift on a shrinking ice fragment, facing death. He then sees Walton's vessel. He constructs oars from his sledge and, with immense effort, reaches Walton's ship, where he is rescued, his "task unfulfilled."

Frankenstein concludes his narrative by imploring Walton to continue his quest for vengeance and destroy the monster if he appears after Victor's death, warning him not to trust the creature's eloquence.

Walton continues his letters. Frankenstein's health declines rapidly, and he is confined to bed. The crew, fearful for their lives amid the ice, demand Walton turn the ship homeward if a passage opens. Frankenstein, momentarily revived, delivers an impassioned speech, shaming them for their "cowardice" and urging them to continue their glorious enterprise. The sailors are moved, but Frankenstein collapses again. Walton reluctantly agrees to turn back if a passage is found.

On September 9th, the ice breaks up, and a passage south opens. The sailors rejoice. Frankenstein, waking, asks the cause of the tumult. When told they are returning to England, he asserts his heavenly assigned purpose to destroy the monster and attempts to rise, but collapses again, near death. He eventually speaks to Walton, reiterating his conviction that he was right to refuse the monster a companion, as his duty to mankind outweighed his duty to his creature. He again asks Walton to fulfill his vengeful task, though he then qualifies it, leaving it to Walton's judgment and advising him to "seek happiness in tranquillity and and avoid ambition." Frankenstein then dies peacefully.

Later that night, Walton hears sounds from the cabin where Frankenstein's body lies. He enters to find the gigantic monster hanging over Frankenstein's coffin, expressing self-reproach and calling Frankenstein his "last victim." Walton confronts the monster, accusing him of hypocrisy. The monster explains that his crimes were driven by the "insatiable thirst for vengeance" born from his misery and the universal hatred he received, particularly after Frankenstein denied him a companion. He recalls Felix's rejection and the rustic's attack. He details his murders of William, Justine, Clerval, and Elizabeth, admitting his "demoniacal design became an insatiable passion." He expresses extreme self-loathing, calling himself an "abortion." The monster declares his work is complete and vows to end his own existence by building a funeral pyre in the northernmost reaches of the globe and consuming himself to ashes, ensuring no trace of his existence remains to tempt another creator. He bids farewell to Walton, the last human he will ever see, and springs from the cabin window onto an ice raft, vanishing into the darkness.

The story begins with Pip, an orphan living in the marsh country of England with his older, harsh sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery, and her kind blacksmith husband, Joe Gargery. One raw afternoon in the churchyard, Pip is terrified by an escaped convict, who threatens him with death if he doesn't bring him food and a file to the old Battery on the marshes the next morning. The convict also mentions a mysterious "young man" who would further harm Pip if he failed.

Pip, consumed by fear and guilt, steals a pork pie, some bread, mincemeat, brandy, and a file from his sister's pantry and Joe's forge on Christmas Eve. His sister's strictness and Joe's innocent unawareness exacerbate his distress. On Christmas Day, during a family dinner with Mr. Wopsle (the church clerk), Mr. and Mrs. Hubble, and Uncle Pumblechook, Pip substitutes tar-water for brandy, causing Pumblechook a violent fit. The commotion is interrupted when soldiers arrive at their door, needing Joe to mend handcuffs for escaped convicts. Pip and Joe, along with Mr. Wopsle, join the soldiers in a hunt on the marshes. They find two convicts, Magwitch (Pip's convict) and Compeyson (the "young man" Magwitch had threatened Pip with), fighting in a ditch. Magwitch claims he captured Compeyson. Compeyson accuses Magwitch of attempted murder. Both are apprehended, and Magwitch is taken to a prison-ship. Before he leaves, Magwitch admits to the sergeant that he stole the pie and food from the blacksmith's. Joe, with generous compassion, tells him he was welcome to it. Pip, however, is relieved but still haunted by his secret.

Over the next months, Mrs. Joe suffers a severe head injury from an unknown assailant, leaving her sight, hearing, and speech impaired. A filed convict's leg-iron is found nearby. Pip suspects either Orlick (Joe's morose journeyman) or the "strange man" (Compeyson, whom Pip had seen in the Jolly Bargemen before) of the attack. Biddy, Joe's kind helper, eventually deduces that Mrs. Joe's cryptic chalk drawings of a hammer refer to Orlick. Mrs. Joe, strangely, shows propitiation towards Orlick after this. Meanwhile, Pip continues his uncomfortable weekly visits to Miss Havisham, an eccentric, wealthy lady who lives in Satis House, a decaying mansion where time stopped at twenty minutes to nine on her wedding day. There, Estella, Miss Havisham's beautiful but cruel adopted daughter, treats Pip with disdain, mocking his "coarse hands" and "thick boots." Pip falls in love with Estella, but she tells him she has "no heart." Pip also has an encounter with a "pale young gentleman" in Miss Havisham's garden, resulting in a fight that Pip wins. Later, he discovers this is Herbert Pocket.

In his fourth year of apprenticeship, Pip learns from Mr. Jaggers, a London lawyer, that he has "great expectations" from an unknown benefactor. He is to be educated as a gentleman in London. Jaggers, who is Miss Havisham's lawyer, becomes Pip's guardian. Joe, heartbroken but unselfish, agrees to release Pip from his apprenticeship. Uncle Pumblechook, however, falsely claims credit for Pip's new fortune. Pip, ashamed of his humble origins, leaves his village and Joe, believing Miss Havisham is his secret benefactress and intends him for Estella.

In London, Pip lives with Herbert Pocket, who becomes his close friend. Herbert, a hopeful but impractical "capitalist," reveals Miss Havisham's tragic story: she was betrayed and jilted by her fiancé, Compeyson, who conspired with her half-brother Arthur to swindle her. Pip begins his education with Herbert's father, Mr. Matthew Pocket, a kind but distracted tutor, and meets other students, including the sulky and unpleasant Bentley Drummle. Pip and Herbert accrue debts in their new, lavish lifestyle.

Pip also frequently interacts with Wemmick, Jaggers's clerk, who maintains a strict separation between his professional, severe "office" persona and his warm, eccentric "Walworth" persona at his "Castle" home, where he cares for his deaf "Aged Parent." Wemmick introduces Pip to his collection of "portable property," which includes casts of executed criminals. Jaggers invites Pip and his friends to dinner, where he forces his housekeeper, Molly, to display her strong, scarred wrists. This, combined with Wemmick's later revelations, leads Pip to deduce that Molly is Estella's mother, a woman acquitted of murder, whom Jaggers defended and then "tamed."

Estella, now in London, continues to captivate Pip but treats him coldly. She informs him she is to marry Bentley Drummle, devastating Pip. Wopsle, now a struggling actor in London, recognizes Compeyson (the other convict) in the audience at one of his plays. Pip is horrified by the danger this poses.

Soon after, Magwitch, Pip's actual benefactor, secretly returns to London, risking his life, as he was sentenced to transportation for life. He proudly reveals to Pip that he made him a gentleman. Pip is initially horrified by Magwitch's commonness and criminal past. Magwitch recounts his life story, confirming his connection to Compeyson and Arthur, and his trial where Compeyson framed him. Herbert reveals that Compeyson was indeed Miss Havisham's betraying fiancé.

Realizing Magwitch is in grave danger, Pip and Herbert devise a plan to get him out of England. They hide Magwitch (under the alias Mr. Campbell) at the house of Mrs. Whimple, where Herbert's fiancée, Clara Barley, lives with her loud, gout-ridden father. Herbert and Startop begin practicing rowing for the escape.

Pip receives an anonymous note, luring him to the sluice-house on the marshes for information about "your uncle Provis" (Magwitch). Pip goes alone and is ambushed by Orlick, who ties him up, revealing he was the one who attacked Mrs. Joe with the leg-iron, and that he intends to kill Pip in the limekiln. Orlick blames Pip for his misfortunes. Pip is rescued by Herbert and Startop, who followed him after finding his dropped letter and becoming suspicious. Orlick flees but is later arrested for breaking into Pumblechook's house.

The escape plan for Magwitch is put into motion. Pip, Herbert, and Startop row Magwitch down the Thames to meet a foreign steamer. They are intercepted by a galley containing officers and Compeyson. In the ensuing struggle, Magwitch and Compeyson fall overboard. Magwitch is gravely injured and recaptured, but Compeyson drowns.

Magwitch, severely wounded, is taken to prison, where he is tried for returning from transportation and sentenced to death. Pip visits him daily, growing to love and respect the man who made his fortune. In Magwitch's final days, Pip reveals to him that his long-lost daughter (Estella) is alive, beautiful, and a lady. Magwitch dies peacefully, placing Pip's hand on his chest.

Following Magwitch's death, Pip falls gravely ill. Joe comes to London and nurses him with unwavering love and kindness. Pip learns that Mrs. Joe had died while he was ill and that Orlick has been imprisoned for robbing Pumblechook. He also discovers that Joe, without telling him, had paid off all his debts. Humbled and full of remorse for his past ingratitude, Pip resolves to return to Joe and Biddy, confess his changed heart, and propose a future with them. When he returns to his village, he finds Biddy has married Joe. He expresses his profound gratitude and love for them, promising to repay his debt and wishing them happiness.

Pip sells his remaining possessions to settle his debts and leaves England to join Herbert and Clara, who are now married, at Clarriker and Co. in the East. Many years later, Herbert learns that Pip had secretly funded his partnership.

Eleven years after leaving England, Pip returns to his old home. He finds Joe and Biddy happily married with a child, whom they have named Pip. Pip visits the ruins of Satis House, which is being dismantled. He encounters Estella there. She is a widow, having suffered greatly from her cruel marriage to Drummle. Her beauty has faded, but her eyes now hold a "saddened, softened light," and her touch is "friendly." Estella confesses that suffering has taught her to understand his heart and what she once "threw away." They acknowledge their past and agree to remain friends. As the evening mists rise, Pip leaves, feeling "no shadow of another parting from her."

The match begins. Hamlet scores the first hit, confirmed by Osric. The King offers Hamlet the poisoned cup, but Hamlet defers, saying he will play "this bout first." Hamlet scores a second hit. The Queen then drinks from the cup, despite the King's warning, saying, "I pray you, pardon me." The King mutters, "It is the poison'd cup; it is too late." Laertes, now conflicted, knows he must hit Hamlet. They play a third bout. Laertes wounds Hamlet with his poisoned rapier. In the ensuing scuffle, they exchange rapiers, and Hamlet wounds Laertes with the same poisoned blade.
The Queen falls back, declaring, "The drink, the drink! I am poison'd." Laertes falls, revealing his own treachery: Hamlet is slain by the "treacherous instrument" (the poisoned rapier) in his hand, and he himself is "justly killed with mine own treachery." He explicitly states, "Thy mother's poison'd: I can no more: the king, the king's to blame." Hamlet, realizing the full extent of the plot, plunges the poisoned rapier into the King, forcing him to drink from the poisoned cup, saying, "Here, thou incestuous, murd'rous, damnèd Dane, Follow my mother." The King dies. Laertes exchanges forgiveness with Hamlet before he dies.
Hamlet, dying, asks Horatio to live and "Report me and my cause aright To the unsatisfied." Horatio, declaring himself "more an antique Roman than a Dane," attempts to drink the remaining poison from the cup to join Hamlet, but Hamlet violently stops him, begging him to tell his story. Hamlet dies, with the final words, "The rest is silence." A "Dead March" sounds afar off as the curtain descends.

The provided text details the life and experiences of Jane Eyre from her childhood at Gateshead Hall, through her education and teaching at Lowood Institution, to her time as a governess at Thornfield Hall, and finally to her union with Mr. Rochester and the subsequent years.

**Chapter I:**
The narrator, Jane Eyre, is a young orphan living with her aunt, Mrs. Reed, and cousins Eliza, John, and Georgiana Reed, at Gateshead Hall. On a cold, rainy winter day, Mrs. Reed excludes Jane from the family group in the drawing-room, citing Jane’s unsociable and unchildlike disposition. Jane retreats to a window-seat in the adjoining breakfast-room to read "Bewick’s History of British Birds," finding solace in its bleak imagery. Her cousin John Reed enters, verbally abuses her, and throws the book at her, hitting her head and drawing blood. In a rare outburst, Jane calls John a "wicked and cruel boy," comparing him to a murderer and Roman emperors. John attacks her, prompting Mrs. Reed, Bessie (the nurse), and Abbot (the maid) to intervene. Mrs. Reed, enraged that Jane "flew at Master John," orders her to be taken to the "red-room" and locked in as punishment.

**Chapter II:**
Jane resists Bessie and Abbot's attempts to take her to the red-room, a large, rarely used chamber where Mr. Reed had died. They scold her for her "shocking conduct" and tell her she is "less than a servant." Bessie threatens to tie her down if she does not sit still. Jane complies, feeling the ignominy. Left alone in the red-room, Jane is filled with fear and resentment over the injustice of her treatment at Gateshead. She reflects on her dependency and Mrs. Reed’s broken promise to her deceased uncle to raise Jane as her own. Believing the room to be haunted by Mr. Reed’s spirit, she is terrified when she sees a gleam of light on the wall. She screams and desperately shakes the locked door. Bessie and Abbot return, and Jane cries that she saw a light and thought a ghost would come. Abbot dismisses it as a trick. Mrs. Reed arrives, scolds the servants, and punishes Jane further for her "artifice" by forcing her to remain in the red-room for another hour. Jane pleads for mercy but is thrust back in and loses consciousness.

**Chapter III:**
Jane wakes in her own bed in the nursery, disoriented. She sees the apothecary, Mr. Lloyd, examining her. His presence, as a stranger unrelated to the Reeds, brings her a sense of protection. Mr. Lloyd questions her about her illness. Jane reveals she was "knocked down" by John and then locked in the red-room, which she believes is haunted by Mr. Reed's ghost. She admits to being miserable due to her lack of family. Mr. Lloyd asks about her relatives, and Jane mentions her aunt once spoke of "poor, low relations called Eyre." Jane expresses a desire to leave Gateshead and, when asked, states she would like to go to school. Mr. Lloyd speaks to Mrs. Reed, recommending "change of air and scene" for Jane. Jane later overhears Bessie and Abbot discussing her, confirming that her parents died of typhus a year after marrying against her grandfather Reed's wishes, leaving her orphaned and disinherited. Abbot expresses disdain for Jane, wishing she were a "nice, pretty child." Jane's hopes for a new life are kindled. A week later, Mr. Lloyd's reply to Miss Temple corroborates Jane's story. Miss Temple publicly clears Jane's name before the entire school. Jane, relieved, applies herself diligently to her studies and quickly advances, learning French and drawing. She finds purpose and contentment in her new life at Lowood.

**Chapter IV:**
As weeks pass at Lowood, Jane regains her health. However, in early spring, a severe typhus fever epidemic strikes the school, sickening forty-five out of eighty girls and turning the institution into a hospital. Mr. Brocklehurst and his family avoid Lowood during this time. The strict housekeeper, Mrs. Harden, leaves, and her more liberal successor improves the food provisions. Jane, among the healthy students, enjoys increased freedom to roam the surrounding moors and woods. She forms a close friendship with Helen Burns, a fellow student who patiently endures Miss Scatcherd's harsh punishments and embodies a philosophy of Christian endurance and forgiveness. Helen suffers from consumption, not typhus, and is moved to Miss Temple's room. Jane, ignorant of the severity of consumption, is only vaguely concerned. One evening, after seeing the surgeon's pony at Lowood, Jane learns from a nurse that Helen is dying. Jane secretly visits Helen that night and finds her composed and serene. Helen speaks of her belief in God and a happy afterlife. Jane falls asleep in Helen's arms. The next morning, Jane is carried back to her dormitory, and soon learns that Helen has died. Helen's grave is marked with "Resurgam."

**Chapter X:**
Eight years pass. Jane remains at Lowood, six as a pupil and two as a teacher. The typhus epidemic led to public scrutiny and reforms at Lowood: a new building, better diet, and a governing committee. Mr. Brocklehurst retains his treasury post but with less power. Jane flourishes, becoming the first girl in her class and then a respected teacher. However, her solace, Miss Temple, marries and moves away, leaving Jane feeling a void and a renewed longing for liberty and change. Jane secretly advertises for a governess position and receives one offer from a Mrs. Fairfax of Thornfield, near Millcote, for thirty pounds a year to teach one pupil. Mrs. Reed, contacted for a reference, replies that Jane "might do as she pleased." Jane receives a positive testimonial from Lowood. Before leaving, she is visited by Bessie, who is now married to Robert Leaven and has children. Bessie updates Jane on the Reed family: John Reed has died, reportedly by suicide, after ruining himself and his family; Mrs. Reed suffered a stroke and is very ill. Bessie also reveals that Jane's paternal uncle, Mr. Eyre from Madeira, visited Gateshead seven years ago, wanting to adopt Jane, but Mrs. Reed turned him away. Jane leaves Lowood, heading for Thornfield Hall.

**Chapter XI:**
Jane arrives in Millcote late at night and is met by a servant who drives her to Thornfield Hall, six miles away. She is surprised by Mrs. Fairfax, who, contrary to Jane's expectations of a stately mistress, is a kind, elderly housekeeper, distantly related to the Rochesters. Mrs. Fairfax explains that Mr. Rochester owns Thornfield and that Adèle Varens, Jane's pupil, is his ward. Adèle and her French nurse, Sophie, soon appear. Adèle, a lively French child, speaks of her past life with her mother, Céline Varens, a French opera-dancer, and her journey with Mr. Rochester. Jane begins teaching Adèle in the library. Mrs. Fairfax gives Jane a tour of the grand old house, including the unused third-story rooms. Jane hears a strange, mirthless laugh from the third floor, which Mrs. Fairfax attributes to Grace Poole, a servant who works and lives in that area. Jane finds Grace Poole to be a hard-featured, plain woman, and is puzzled by the laugh and Grace's unusual position.

Jane settles into Thornfield. Adèle becomes more obedient, and Jane develops affection for her and Mrs. Fairfax. She later discovers this man is Mr. Rochester, the master of Thornfield Hall, who has just returned.

**Chapter XIII:**
Mr. Rochester, recovering from his sprained ankle, keeps Jane and Adèle at a distance, busy with his business callers. He sends for them to join him for tea. Jane, despite Mrs. Fairfax's suggestion of formality, attends in her usual simple attire. Mr. Rochester is stern but engages Jane in conversation. He comments on her unusual appearance and intelligence. He shows her his portfolio of drawings, which are imaginative and dark, asking about the inspiration behind them. Jane admits to finding great pleasure in creating them. He then abruptly dismisses her and Adèle. Mrs. Fairfax reveals details about Mr. Rochester's past: he inherited Thornfield after his elder brother's death and had a troubled history, including "misunderstandings" with his father and brother. That night, Jane is awakened by a "demoniac laugh" and a struggle outside her door. She smells smoke and discovers Mr. Rochester's bed curtains are on fire. She quickly extinguishes the flames, drenching Mr. Rochester. He wakes, confused, and reveals he was attacked. He instructs Jane to tell no one and attributes the incident to Grace Poole, whom he then goes to confront upstairs. He returns, pale and gloomy, confirming it was Grace Poole but insists Jane keep silent and he will account for it. He expresses gratitude to Jane for saving his life.

**Chapter XIV:**
The next morning, Jane observes Grace Poole calmly sewing new curtains in Mr. Rochester's room, showing no signs of guilt, which baffles Jane. Grace offers a plausible but false explanation for the fire. Jane, testing Grace, asks more questions, making Grace subtly suspicious of Jane's knowledge. Jane's indignation at Grace's apparent impunity is tempered by her desire for self-preservation. Jane deduces a mysterious hold Grace Poole has over Mr. Rochester. Later, Mrs. Fairfax informs Jane that Mr. Rochester has left to attend a party at the Eshton's estate, "The Leas," and is expected to stay for a week or more. She mentions the beautiful and accomplished Blanche Ingram, whom Mr. Rochester is expected to marry. Jane is devastated by this news, realizing her growing love for Mr. Rochester has been foolish. She resolves to crush her feelings by drawing her own "plain" portrait and a beautiful miniature of Blanche Ingram, to remind herself of their differing stations.

**Chapter XV:**
Mr. Rochester later explains the story of Adèle's parentage. She is the daughter of Céline Varens, a French opera-dancer with whom he had a "grande passion." He discovered Céline's infidelity and mercenary nature and ended their relationship. Though Adèle is not his biological daughter, he took her in out of charity after her mother abandoned her. He reveals he feigned courtship of Miss Ingram to make Jane jealous and to test her feelings. He confirms his love for Jane and proposes marriage. Jane, overwhelmed, initially resists, reminding him of their social disparity and his engagement to Miss Ingram. He insists he has no love for Miss Ingram and has already discredited himself to her to expose her true, mercenary character. Jane confesses her love for him. Mr. Rochester quickly takes Jane indoors, telling Mrs. Fairfax they will be married in four weeks.

On the eve of her wedding, Jane is preparing to leave Thornfield. She is unsettled by the "ghostly" wedding attire and an unexplained event from the previous night. Later that night, while waiting for Mr. Rochester's return from a business trip, she is awakened by a "savage, shrilly sound" and a struggle from the third story, followed by a call for "Rochester!" He takes Jane to the orchard, where he explains his tragic marriage to Bertha Mason in Jamaica, a union arranged by his father for money, only to discover Bertha's inherent madness and depravity. He explains his attempt to live with mistresses after being unable to divorce Bertha. He confesses his love for Jane, saying she is his only hope for a "higher and worthier existence." He proposes they live together as husband and wife, but in a "secure sanctuary" in the south of France, away from Thornfield. Jane, though loving him, refuses to be his mistress, affirming her adherence to moral law. She believes she must leave him. That night, a mysterious voice calls "Jane! Jane! Jane!" which Jane recognizes as Mr. Rochester's. She believes it is a supernatural summons.

**Chapter XXVI:**
On the wedding morning, as Jane prepares, the ceremony is interrupted at the church. A solicitor, Mr. Briggs, reveals that Mr. Rochester is already married to Bertha Mason, who is still alive and residing at Thornfield. Mr. Mason, Bertha's brother, is produced as a witness. Mr. Rochester, enraged, admits the truth, calling Bertha his "wife" and a "hideous demon." He leads everyone back to Thornfield Hall, where he unveils Bertha Mason, a wild, corpulent, and terrifying madwoman, who attacks him. He binds her, then confronts the guests, inviting them to judge his situation. Mr. Briggs explains that Jane's uncle, Mr. Eyre of Madeira, who is now ill, had learned of Jane's impending marriage from Mr. Mason and sent him to prevent it, having intended to adopt Jane and leave her his fortune. Jane, devastated by the deception and the revelation of Bertha, retreats to her room. She realizes her love for Mr. Rochester is tainted and that she must leave him. She tells Mr. Rochester she cannot be his mistress. He pleads with her, offering her his hand and all his possessions, insisting he wants to marry her and that she is his "equal." Jane, though loving him, refuses to live with him outside of marriage, citing her principles and self-respect. She asserts her freedom and independent will. After an agonizing struggle, she leaves Thornfield in the dead of night, with only a small amount of money, walking away to an unknown future.

After two days of wandering and starvation, Jane is left penniless at Whitcross, a desolate moorland crossing. She finds temporary shelter on the moor and, after a night of prayer and reflection, resolves to seek work. She is repeatedly refused shelter and food in a nearby village due to her appearance and lack of references. Close to death from hunger and exhaustion, she stumbles upon a small cottage, Moor House, where she is found by Mr. St. John Rivers and his two sisters, Diana and Mary. St. John, a clergyman, brings her inside despite the housekeeper Hannah's suspicions. The sisters, seeing her dire state, offer her food and shelter. Jane, giving the alias Jane Elliott, refuses to disclose her past, fearing discovery. The Rivers family, though compassionate, are intrigued by her.

**Chapter XXIX:**
Jane slowly recovers at Moor House, nursed by Diana and Mary. St. John, though observing her keenly, initially remains reserved. Jane enjoys the intellectual companionship of Diana and Mary and helps with household chores and gooseberry picking. She learns about the Rivers family: their father, the old Mr. Rivers, has recently died, and they are struggling financially. Their uncle, John Eyre, has died and left his entire fortune to an unknown relative, with only thirty guineas for the Rivers siblings. St. John, initially cold towards Jane, reveals his ambition to be a missionary in India. Jane then realizes that St. John, Diana, and Mary are her cousins, as her father was Mr. Rivers's mother's brother. Jane, joyful at finding family, insists on dividing her inheritance (which she discovers is twenty thousand pounds from her uncle John Eyre) equally among the four cousins, giving each five thousand pounds. Jane closes Morton school (where she has become a much-loved schoolmistress) for the holidays and eagerly begins transforming Moor House for Diana and Mary's return, demonstrating her domestic skills and finding joy in her new family connections. Diana and Mary return, expressing delight with the renovated home and Jane's warm welcome. Jane is deeply troubled, realizing he does not love her in a spousal way and that such a marriage would sacrifice her true nature. She struggles with his powerful will, feeling a strong "veneration" for his character but resisting his demand for her entire self. **Chapter XXXV:**
St. John delays his departure for a week, during which he inflicts "refined, lingering torture" on Jane through his coldness and disapproval, making her feel outcast. He constantly reminds her of her "offence." One evening, Jane makes a final attempt to reconcile with him, but he remains unmoved, reiterating his intention to go to India and asking if she will not marry him. Jane firmly refuses, saying he doesn't love her and would "kill me" if she married him. She offers again to go as his assistant, but he rejects the idea of an unmarried female curate. He then accuses her of loving Mr. Rochester. Jane admits this by her silence, confirming his suspicion that her heart "clings" to an "unconsecrated" interest. He leaves, reiterating his prayer that she "may not indeed become a castaway." Diana, knowing St. John has proposed, expresses her concern for Jane's well-being and her unsuitability for a missionary's life. She acknowledges Jane does not love St. John. Jane, meanwhile, is torn by St. John's powerful influence. Just as she is about to yield to his will, she hears a mysterious, urgent voice calling her name, "Jane! Jane! Jane!" She recognizes it as Mr. Rochester's voice. Feeling it is a divine summons, she breaks from St. John, asserting her independence, and resolves to find Mr. Rochester.

**Chapter XXXVI:**
St. John leaves a note for Jane, urging her to "watch and pray" and reconsider his offer. Jane, however, is determined to find Mr. Rochester. She announces to Diana and Mary that she is going on a journey. She travels back to Whitcross, then continues towards Thornfield, where she sees the Hall is a "blackened ruin," destroyed by fire. She returns to the local inn and learns from the host (Mr. Rochester's former butler) that Thornfield Hall burned down in the autumn. The fire was started by Bertha Mason, Mr. Rochester's mad wife, who had escaped her confinement (due to Grace Poole's inattention). Bertha set fire to the house and then threw herself from the roof, dying instantly. Mr. Rochester, after ensuring all the servants were safe, had tried to rescue Bertha. In doing so, he sustained severe injuries: he lost an eye and a hand, and became completely blind. He now lives as a "cripple" at Ferndean, a desolate manor-house, attended only by old John and his wife. Jane immediately hires a chaise to go to him.

**Chapter XXXVII:**
Jane arrives at Ferndean in the evening. She sees Mr. Rochester, now blind and with one arm mutilated, emerging from the house. He is a brooding, desperate figure. He struggles to navigate his surroundings, reliant on John for guidance. Jane, unseen, observes him, feeling a mix of pain and hope. She then enters the house and, without revealing her name, tells John's wife, Mary, that she has come to see Mr. Rochester. Mr. Rochester, who has been living in isolation and despair, rings for candles and water. Jane carries the tray into the parlor. Pilot, Mr. Rochester's dog, recognizes her. Mr. Rochester, unable to see, asks who is there. Jane speaks, and he recognizes her voice. He reaches out, grasps her hand, then embraces her, overwhelmed with emotion, questioning if she is real or a dream. Jane assures him she is real and has returned to him. She reveals her uncle in Madeira is dead and has left her five thousand pounds, making her an "independent woman." She tells Mr. Rochester she will stay with him as his companion, eyes, and hands. He is initially reserved but slowly opens up. Jane, teasing him about his appearance, begins to restore his spirits. He asks her to marry him, accepting his infirmities. Jane joyfully accepts, affirming her love for him and her delight in being useful to him. Mr. Rochester confesses that God's "chastisements" (his suffering) have humbled him, leading him to remorse and repentance, and he now sees God's hand in his doom. He recounts his desperate prayer for Jane's return, and how he heard her voice calling to him at midnight. Jane confirms she heard his call at the same time and replied to it. He thanks God for her return and for tempering judgment with mercy.

**Chapter XXXVIII (Conclusion):**
Jane marries Mr. Rochester in a quiet ceremony with only the parson and clerk present. She informs John and Mary at Ferndean, who are pleased. She writes to Diana and Mary Rivers, who approve of her marriage. St. John Rivers, however, does not reply to her letter, though he later maintains a correspondence. Jane soon brings Adèle from her strict school to live with them, finding her a pleasing companion. Ten years pass. Jane and Mr. Rochester live in complete happiness and concord. Mr. Rochester remains blind for the first two years of their marriage, with Jane serving as his "vision" and "right hand," describing the world to him and reading to him. At the end of two years, he recovers sight in one eye, enabling him to discern light and shape, though not distinctly. When their first-born son is placed in his arms, he can see the boy's eyes, which are like his own once were. He again thanks God for His mercy. Diana and Mary Rivers both marry and visit them annually. St. John Rivers goes to India as a missionary, where he continues his zealous work, remaining unmarried. Jane's last letter from him implies his imminent death, as he eagerly awaits his heavenly reward, having dedicated his life to God's service. The book concludes with Jane and Mr. Rochester's enduring happiness.

The narrative begins with the introduction of Charles Bovary, a new and awkward fifteen-year-old student, at school. His unusual cap and stammered name, which sounds like "Charbovari," cause widespread laughter and punishment from the master. Despite his initial discomfort, Charles applies himself diligently to his studies.

His background is then detailed: his father, Monsieur Charles Denis Bartolome Bovary, a former assistant-surgeon-major, was compromised in conscription scandals and forced to leave service. He married a hosier's daughter for her sixty thousand franc dowry, but squandered the fortune on extravagant living. Charles's mother, initially loving, grew bitter due to her husband's philandering and irresponsibility, taking over the household management while he idled. Charles, their son, was spoiled in childhood and received irregular, insufficient education from the local curé. At sixteen, he was sent to school in Rouen, where he was an average student. His parents later withdrew him to study medicine. Initially overwhelmed by the curriculum, he eventually became idle, frequenting public-houses and pursuing casual relationships. He failed his first examination but passed a subsequent one after intense cramming.

Charles set up his medical practice in Tostes, succeeding a deceased doctor. His mother then arranged his marriage to Madame Dubuc, a forty-five-year-old widow with a twelve hundred franc income, despite her unattractive appearance. Charles hoped for an easier life, but his wife was controlling, dictating his behavior, managing his finances, and showing constant jealousy and complaints about her health.

One night, Charles is called to the Bertaux farm to treat Monsieur Rouault, a prosperous farmer, for a broken leg. There, he meets Emma, Monsieur Rouault’s daughter, who helps manage the farm. Charles is captivated by Emma’s delicate hands and candid eyes. He treats the simple fracture and begins to visit the farm frequently, enjoying Emma's company. His wife, Heloise, becomes intensely jealous, making allusions and open criticisms of Emma's background, leading Charles to reluctantly cease his visits. Soon after, it is discovered that Heloise's supposed fortune was largely fabricated, with a notary absconding with funds and her property heavily mortgaged. Charles's father, enraged by the deception, blames his wife for Charles's marriage. A week later, Heloise suffers a hemorrhage and dies suddenly. Charles is left in a sorrowful reverie, realizing her love for him.

After Heloise's death, old Rouault visits Charles, offering condolences and inviting him back to the Bertaux, implying Emma misses him. Charles accepts, finding solace in the visits and a naive sense of freedom in his independence. He resolves to propose to Emma. Old Rouault, facing his own financial troubles, readily agrees to the match, and Emma signals her acceptance by opening a shutter. The wedding is set for the following spring, after Charles's period of mourning. Emma meticulously prepares her trousseau, though she had dreamed of a more romantic, torch-lit wedding, which her father dismissed. The wedding is a large, sixteen-hour affair with many guests, abundant food, and lively entertainment. Charles, though quiet, is openly affectionate with Emma the next day, calling her "my wife." Two days later, they depart for Tostes, with old Rouault experiencing a wave of nostalgia and sadness upon their departure.

In Tostes, Emma immediately begins redecorating Charles's house, making it more elegant, and Charles buys her a dogcart. Charles is completely enamored with Emma, finding joy in every detail of her presence and believing himself to be the happiest of men. Emma, however, feels a profound sense of disillusionment, questioning if she truly loved Charles and longing for the "felicity, passion, rapture" she had read about in books. Her past is explored, revealing a childhood steeped in romantic novels and a convent education that fostered a desire for excitement and grand emotions, rather than the mundane realities of country life. She felt herself destined for something more, a "wondrous passion" that Charles's calm, commonplace nature could not provide.

Emma grows increasingly bored and irritated by Charles's lack of ambition, his coarse habits, and the provincial mediocrity of their life. She retreats into her dreams, poring over Parisian journals and novels, imagining a life of luxury and passion. She becomes capricious and neglects her household. Her relationship with Charles's mother, who critiques Emma's spending and "fine ways," becomes strained, leading to arguments. Emma suffers from palpitations, fits of temper, and fainting spells. Charles, attributing her illness to the environment, decides to move to Yonville-l’Abbaye, a market town where a doctor has recently left. Emma, while tidying, finds her old wedding bouquet and burns it, symbolizing the end of her past illusions. They leave Tostes, with Emma pregnant.

In Yonville, a detailed description of the town reveals its provincial stagnation, from the notary's house to the chemist's shop of Monsieur Homais. Homais, a self-important and talkative figure, is introduced, along with Binet, the punctual tax-collector. Charles and Emma arrive, and Homais, eager to curry favor due to his own past legal issues regarding practicing medicine without a diploma, immediately befriends Charles. He offers advice and gifts. Emma and Léon Dupuis, a notary's clerk, meet and discover a shared sensibility, bonding over conversations about nature, music, and literature, and their mutual boredom with Yonville. Léon is captivated by Emma.

Emma gives birth to a girl, Berthe, causing her to faint in disappointment, as she had hoped for a son. She struggles to name the child, eventually settling on Berthe after a name she heard at Vaubyessard. Homais becomes godfather, offering pharmaceutical products as gifts. A chaotic baptism dinner ensues, where Charles's father baptizes Berthe with champagne, angering the curé. Charles's father flirts with Emma, alarming his wife who then orchestrates their departure. Emma, restless, visits Berthe, who is being nursed by the carpenter's wife, Mere Rollet. Léon accompanies her, and their walk by the river deepens their connection, though Léon is too timid to act on his feelings. Emma feels a growing passion for Léon but is also restrained by pride and shame.

Emma's dissatisfaction intensifies. She sees Charles as an obstacle to her happiness and directs her hatred and frustration towards him. She fantasizes about a more exciting life with Léon. Her behavior changes; she feigns piety and domesticity, even bringing Berthe home to showcase a maternal side. Léon is confused by her mixed signals and begins to lose hope, placing her on an "extraordinary pinnacle." Emma, however, is consumed by internal desires and resentment. She suffers from fainting spells and spitting blood, which Charles attributes to nervousness. Charles, desperate to cure her, agrees to Homais's suggestion for him to perform an experimental surgery on Hippolyte, the club-footed stable-boy, to gain fame and money. Emma encourages this, eager for Charles's success to reflect well on her.

Charles, after studying, operates on Hippolyte, cutting his Achilles tendon. The operation initially seems successful, and Homais writes a self-aggrandizing article for the local paper, praising Charles. However, Hippolyte's condition rapidly deteriorates; gangrene sets in. Charles is forced to call in a renowned surgeon, Monsieur Canivet, who scorns Charles's botched procedure and amputates Hippolyte's leg. Charles is devastated and humiliated. Emma is furious, not for Charles's failure, but for her own misplaced hope in his mediocrity. She lashes out at him, smashing a barometer. That evening, Rodolphe Boulanger, the wealthy landowner, visits and finds Emma waiting for him. They embrace, their affair rekindled.

Emma and Rodolphe continue their secret rendezvous, with Emma becoming more brazen. She wants to elope with him, imagining a life of passion and luxury in exotic lands. Rodolphe, however, is reluctant to take on a child or the responsibilities of a serious commitment. He delays their departure repeatedly. Meanwhile, Emma's financial affairs spiral out of control. She signs numerous bills with Lheureux, the draper and moneylender, to fund her extravagant purchases and desires. She also sells a small property without Charles's knowledge. Her debts rapidly mount.

Rodolphe eventually writes Emma a letter, hidden in a basket of apricots, ending their affair. He claims he cannot bring misery into her life and must sacrifice himself by exile. Emma, upon reading the letter, is devastated. Overwhelmed with despair, she contemplates suicide, going to the attic window and feeling drawn to the abyss, but Charles's voice pulls her back. She returns downstairs, tries to eat, and then, upon seeing Rodolphe's tilbury pass by, she collapses, recognizing him. She falls into a brain fever. Charles, distraught, nurses her for weeks, calling in doctors, including his old master, Dr. Lariviere, who pronounces her case hopeless.

During her illness, Emma experiences a religious conversion, believing she will become a saint. She embraces Christian humility, praying and engaging in charity, sewing clothes for the poor and bringing Berthe home. Her mother-in-law, who briefly returns, attributes Emma's change to her illness. However, Emma's piety is also a means of masking her internal turmoil and her continued longing for a passionate life. She receives more summonses for unpaid debts. She attempts to get money from Léon, who is now a notary's clerk in Rouen. He is timid and unsuccessful in finding the large sum she needs. She then tries to persuade Monsieur Guillaumin, the Yonville notary, who attempts to seduce her in exchange for assistance. Emma furiously rejects him, feeling further violated and isolated. She then approaches Binet, the tax-collector, who is working on his lathe, but he is repulsed by her desperate advances.

In utter despair and feeling lost, Emma remembers Rodolphe's supposed generosity and sets off for his château, La Huchette. She confronts him, confessing her love and despair, and begs him for three thousand francs to save her from financial ruin. Rodolphe calmly tells her he does not have the money. Emma is enraged, pointing out his luxurious possessions and accusing him of never truly loving her, of having ruined her life. She throws his cufflinks away in fury. Rodolphe remains impassive, stating, "I haven't got them." Emma flees, consumed by a whirlwind of emotions, feeling madness approaching.

Driven by a desperate impulse, Emma runs to Homais's chemist shop, sneaks into his private laboratory ("Capharnaum"), and takes a jar of arsenic, which she immediately consumes. Justin, Homais's apprentice, witnesses her act and cries out, but Emma silences him, threatening to blame Homais. She returns home, feeling a false serenity.

Charles, returning home, is distraught by the news of the impending distraint. Emma writes a letter, seals it, and tells Charles to read it tomorrow, refusing to answer any questions. She lies in bed, feeling the poison take effect. She experiences a bitter taste, thirst, sickness, and coldness spreading through her body. At eight o'clock, she begins vomiting blood. Charles notices white sediment in the basin. She denies poisoning herself. She is seized with convulsions and screams. Charles reads her letter, which says, "Accuse no one." He realizes she is poisoned and cries for help.

Doctors Canivet and Lariviere are summoned. Dr. Lariviere, a renowned and respected surgeon, immediately recognizes the gravity of the situation and tells Charles there is nothing more to be done. Homais tries to assert his medical knowledge and offers breakfast to the doctors. Charles is consumed by grief. Emma asks for her child, Berthe, who is brought to her. Berthe innocently remarks on her mother's appearance, then asks about her missing stocking, reminding Emma of her betrayals. Emma turns her head away in loathing. Emma experiences extreme pain and convulsions, rejecting Charles's attempts to help her drink.

As she is dying, the blind man's song, "Maids in the warmth of a summer day / Dream of love, and of love always," is heard outside. Emma raises herself, fixed, staring, and laughs an "atrocious, frantic, despairing laugh," before falling back dead.

A state of shock follows Emma's death. Charles is inconsolable. Homais quickly invents a story that Emma mistook arsenic for sugar. He consoles Charles and helps with funeral arrangements. Charles, in his grief, insists Emma be buried in her wedding dress with a wreath and her hair spread out, in three coffins. Homais and the curé, present at the wake, engage in theological and philosophical arguments, occasionally falling asleep. Charles, drawn to Emma's body, tries to revive her with magnetism. Charles's mother arrives, and they quarrel over funeral expenses. Homais cuts a lock of Emma's hair for Charles. The undertaker's men arrive, and Charles endures the hammering of the coffin. Old Rouault arrives and faints at the sight of the black cloth.

Old Rouault, having received the news late and ambiguously, rushes to Yonville in anguish, suffering hallucinations. At the funeral, he and Charles sit side-by-side. Charles is filled with rage, then resignation, feeling a "vague satisfaction that it was all over." Hippolyte, with his new wooden leg, attends the funeral. Charles throws a five-franc piece at a chorister. At the cemetery, the coffin is lowered, and Charles throws earth on it, crying "Adieu!" He is led away, calmer. Old Rouault, too, departs, promising Charles a turkey. Charles's mother moves in with him.

Money troubles persist for Charles. Lheureux continues to press him for debts, some of which Emma had incurred with false receipts. Félicité, the servant, eventually runs away with Theodore, stealing the remaining clothes. Charles receives news of Léon's marriage. One day, he finds Rodolphe's letter, confirming Emma's affair, but Charles, shrinking from the truth, chooses to believe it was a platonic love. He becomes consumed by a mournful, idealised love for Emma, adopting her tastes and habits, even as he is forced to sell off their possessions. Their daughter, Berthe, is poorly cared for and often sad.

Homais, meanwhile, flourishes. He wages a campaign against the blind man through newspaper articles, eventually having him confined to an asylum. This success emboldens Homais, who uses his journalism to promote his own views and attack rivals. He writes a book, expands his business, and covets the Legion of Honor. Charles and Homais travel to Rouen to choose a mausoleum for Emma, on which Homais suggests the inscription "Tread upon a loving wife." Charles is forgetting Emma, though he dreams of her decaying in his arms.

Eventually, Charles meets Rodolphe at a market. Charles gazes at Rodolphe, seeing something of Emma in him, and wishes he could have been that man. A moment of dark fury passes over Charles, but then he resigns himself, saying, "I don't blame you," and attributing everything to "fatality." The next day, Berthe finds Charles dead in the arbor, a long tress of Emma's black hair in his hand. A post-mortem finds nothing.

After all their possessions are sold, the remaining money is used to send Berthe to her grandmother. The grandmother dies, old Rouault is paralyzed, and Berthe is sent to an aunt who makes her work in a cotton-factory. In Yonville, three doctors fail to succeed due to Homais's relentless attacks. Homais gains an enormous practice, is respected by authorities, and receives the cross of the Legion of Honor.

Clarissa Dalloway, a fifty-two-year-old woman recovering from an illness, begins her day by deciding to buy flowers herself for a party she is hosting that evening. Her maid, Lucy, is busy preparing their Westminster home for the event, which includes removing doors from their hinges for a smoother flow. As Clarissa walks through London, she reflects on her youth at Bourton, recalling her vibrant past and memories of Peter Walsh, an old suitor. She remembers Peter's distinctive personality, his criticisms, and his eventual marriage to a woman in India. Clarissa contrasts her choice to marry Richard Dalloway, which offered her independence, with Peter's passionate intensity, which she felt would have "destroyed" them both.

Clarissa encounters Hugh Whitbread, an old friend, who informs her his wife, Evelyn, is ill. Clarissa feels a familiar sense of inadequacy beside Hugh, but also a quiet attachment. She visits a bookshop, seeking a gift for Evelyn, but finds nothing suitable. She reflects on her own self-perception, feeling both young and aged, and questions the superficiality of her life, including her parties. She acknowledges a deep-seated hatred for Miss Kilman, her daughter Elizabeth's religious and impoverished tutor, viewing her as a "brutal monster" who threatens her daughter's soul and privacy.

Meanwhile, Septimus Warren Smith, a shell-shocked war veteran, is in Regent's Park with his young Italian wife, Lucrezia (Rezia). They witness a motor car with drawn blinds stop, sparking rumors of royalty being inside. Septimus, already suffering from severe mental distress, interprets the event as a terrifying personal sign. He hallucinates that the world is about to burst into flames and feels he is blocking the way. Rezia, desperate and exhausted by his condition, tries to make him engage with reality as advised by Dr. Holmes, their general practitioner. Septimus, however, sees the world through a lens of delusion: an aeroplane writing "messages" in the sky, sparrows singing in Greek about "no crime" and "no death," and his dead friend Evans appearing. Rezia, unable to cope, momentarily wishes him dead.

Back at Clarissa's home, Richard Dalloway arrives unexpectedly from a lunch with Lady Bruton, holding a bunch of red and white roses. He had intended to tell Clarissa he loved her, but cannot bring himself to say the words. Clarissa receives the flowers, understanding his unspoken sentiment. They discuss Peter's unexpected return and his announcement that he is in love with a married woman in India and is seeking a divorce. Clarissa initially feels a pang of regret, briefly imagining a life with Peter, but quickly reaffirms her current life. Richard leaves for a committee meeting, and Clarissa, reflecting on his "divine simplicity," feels a sudden, inexplicable unhappiness, which she identifies as the unjust criticism of her parties by both Peter and Richard.

Elizabeth Dalloway enters, a quiet, serious young woman with an "Oriental mystery" about her. Miss Kilman, her tutor, is listening at the door.
