Nick Carraway, the narrator, moves from the Middle West to West Egg, Long Island, in the spring of 1922 to learn the bond business. He rents a small house next door to a colossal mansion belonging to a mysterious man named Gatsby.

Nick visits his second cousin once removed, Daisy Buchanan, and her wealthy, aggressive husband, Tom Buchanan, at their extravagant home in fashionable East Egg. At their house, Nick meets Jordan Baker, a professional golfer. During dinner, a phone call from New York reveals that Tom has a mistress. Daisy acts cynical and tells Nick about her daughter's birth, expressing a wish for her to be a "beautiful little fool." After leaving the Buchanans, Nick sees Gatsby for the first time, standing on his lawn, stretching his arms towards a single green light at the end of a dock across the bay.

Tom takes Nick to the "valley of ashes," a desolate industrial wasteland, where they stop at a garage owned by George Wilson. Tom's mistress, Myrtle Wilson, George's wife, appears. Myrtle is vital and sensuous, contrasting sharply with her spiritless husband. Tom arranges to meet Myrtle in New York. The three travel to New York (Myrtle in a separate car) and go to an apartment Tom keeps for Myrtle. At a small, raucous party there, Myrtle's sister Catherine and a couple named the McKees are present. Myrtle changes into an elaborate dress and becomes more haughty. Catherine reveals that Tom and Myrtle despise their respective spouses and want to marry, claiming Daisy is Catholic and doesn't believe in divorce (a lie, Nick knows). Myrtle recounts her first meeting with Tom and her disillusionment with George. Later, Tom breaks Myrtle's nose with his open hand when she repeatedly taunts him by shouting Daisy's name. Nick leaves the chaotic scene with Mr. McKee.

Gatsby hosts lavish, uninvited parties every weekend at his mansion. Nick, one of the few invited guests, attends one and, after mingling and hearing various rumors about Gatsby (a German spy, a man who killed someone, Kaiser Wilhelm's nephew), finally meets Gatsby. Gatsby is younger than Nick expected, speaks formally, and calls people "old sport." He recognizes Nick from the war. Nick and Jordan also encounter a man with owl-eyed spectacles in Gatsby's library, astonished that the books are real. After the party, a car crashes outside Gatsby's gate; the drunk driver is not the "owl-eyed" man, but an unidentified passenger.

Gatsby takes Nick to lunch in his opulent yellow car. During the drive, Gatsby tells Nick a fabricated story about his past: being from a wealthy Midwestern family (all dead), educated at Oxford, and a decorated war hero. He shows Nick a medal from Montenegro and an Oxford photo to support his claims. He also uses a "white card" to avoid a speeding ticket from a policeman. In New York, Gatsby introduces Nick to Meyer Wolfshiem, a gambler who fixed the 1919 World's Series and wears human molar cuff buttons. Wolfshiem praises Gatsby's character. Tom Buchanan then enters the restaurant, and Gatsby mysteriously disappears, leaving Nick alone with Wolfshiem. Jordan Baker later explains to Nick that Gatsby's story about being an "Oxford man" is untrue. She then reveals Gatsby's true purpose: he bought his mansion specifically to be across the bay from Daisy, whom he had known and loved as a young army officer in Louisville in 1917. Daisy, after a brief, desperate attempt to call off her wedding, married Tom Buchanan in 1919 and received a $350,000 pearl necklace. Tom had an affair shortly after their honeymoon. Gatsby wants Nick to invite Daisy to tea at his house so Gatsby can "come over" to see her.

Nick agrees to Gatsby's request. On the day of the tea, Gatsby is extremely nervous, sending his gardener to cut Nick's lawn and bringing flowers. Daisy arrives, and her reunion with Gatsby is initially awkward, almost disastrous, but quickly becomes joyful. Gatsby then invites Daisy and Nick to his house, revealing he spent three years earning the money for it, contradicting his earlier claim of inheritance. He gives Daisy a tour, showing off his luxurious possessions, including stacks of imported shirts, which make Daisy cry with emotion. Gatsby points out the green light at the end of Daisy's dock, a symbol of his long-held dream, which he now feels has lost its "colossal significance" because Daisy is physically present. Nick observes Gatsby’s initial bewilderment as the reality of Daisy struggles to match his immense illusion.

Gatsby abruptly stops his parties. His new servants, provided by Wolfshiem, are to prevent gossip because Daisy is now visiting him frequently. Gatsby asks Nick to join him, Daisy, and Jordan for lunch at Daisy's house. During lunch, Daisy openly expresses her love for Gatsby, which Tom notices, leading to a tense confrontation. Daisy introduces her three-year-old daughter, Pammy, to Gatsby, who seems surprised by her existence. Tom, realizing the extent of the affair, insists they all go to New York. In a deliberate act of power, Tom insists on driving Gatsby's yellow car, while Gatsby, Daisy, Nick, and Jordan are to follow in Tom's blue coupé. However, Daisy changes her mind and rides with Gatsby in his yellow car.

On the way to New York in Gatsby's car, Tom confronts Nick and Jordan about their knowledge of the affair. He then exposes Gatsby's illegal activities, revealing Gatsby sold grain alcohol through drugstores with a man named Walter Chase, whom Gatsby left to go to jail. They stop for gas at George Wilson's garage in the valley of ashes. George Wilson is visibly distressed, telling Tom he and Myrtle are moving West because he's discovered Myrtle's infidelity. Myrtle, meanwhile, is seen watching from an upstairs window, mistaking Jordan for Tom's wife and fixing her jealous gaze on her.

At the Plaza Hotel in New York, the confrontation escalates. Tom accuses Gatsby of trying to steal his wife. Gatsby insists Daisy never loved Tom and only married him because she was tired of waiting for Gatsby, who was poor. Daisy, under pressure, reluctantly admits she "did love him once—but I loved you too" to Gatsby. Tom then further exposes Gatsby's illicit businesses, calling him a "common swindler." Daisy, terrified and overwhelmed, withdraws her earlier statements of love and loses her nerve. Tom, feeling triumphant, tells Daisy to go home with Gatsby in Gatsby's car, implying the affair is over. Nick realizes it's his 30th birthday.

As Tom, Jordan, and Nick drive back in Tom's coupé, they pass the valley of ashes. Myrtle Wilson, having been locked in by her distraught husband and agitated by seeing Tom's yellow car earlier, runs out into the road and is struck and instantly killed by a speeding yellow car. Tom, Jordan, and Nick arrive at the scene of the accident. Tom feigns ignorance about the yellow car, telling Wilson that the yellow car was not his and that he was driving a blue coupé, effectively shifting suspicion to Gatsby. Tom carries the grieving Wilson into his office and then leaves with Nick and Jordan, sobbing about the "God damned coward" who didn't stop.

Back at the Buchanan's, Nick sees Tom and Daisy sitting together in the kitchen, seemingly conspiring and united. Nick realizes that Daisy was driving Gatsby's car when she hit and killed Myrtle, and that Gatsby intends to take the blame. Gatsby waits outside the Buchanan's house all night, hoping to protect Daisy, but Nick knows Daisy is safe inside with Tom, who is not thinking of her. Nick leaves Gatsby standing alone in the moonlight, "watching over nothing."

The next morning, Nick goes to Gatsby's house. Gatsby, dejected, tells Nick he had been an impoverished officer when he first met Daisy and had let her believe he was wealthy. He says he committed himself to a "grail" in pursuing her, but she eventually married Tom Buchanan, drawn by Tom's wealth and stability. Nick advises Gatsby to go away, as his car will be traced, but Gatsby refuses to leave Daisy.

Meanwhile, George Wilson, consumed by grief and convinced his wife was murdered by her lover, tells Michaelis (the coffee shop owner) that the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg are the eyes of God, and that God sees everything. He then sets out to find the owner of the yellow car. By tracking the car's path and asking for Gatsby's house, Wilson eventually finds Gatsby floating in his swimming pool on a pneumatic mattress. Gatsby had been waiting for a phone call from Daisy and had instructed his chauffeur not to take out the yellow car, which needed repair. Wilson shoots Gatsby, killing him, and then kills himself.

The police and reporters swarm Gatsby's house. Catherine lies at the inquest to protect her sister's reputation. Nick feels a sense of responsibility for Gatsby, as no one else seems to care. He tries to contact Daisy and Tom, but they have left without a trace. He attempts to reach Meyer Wolfshiem, but Wolfshiem refuses to get involved, stating he "cannot get mixed up in this thing now." A call for Gatsby about illegal bond dealings further hints at his criminal connections.

Gatsby's father, Henry C. Gatz, arrives from Minnesota, a solemn old man who is both distraught and immensely proud of his son's achievements, showing Nick a picture of Gatsby's house and a childhood schedule of self-improvement. Klipspringer, the "boarder," calls, not about the funeral, but to ask for his tennis shoes.

The funeral is poorly attended. Only Nick, Gatsby's father, and the "owl-eyed" man (who earlier marveled at Gatsby's library) are present, along with a few servants and the postman. The "owl-eyed" man expresses shock at the lack of attendees.

Nick decides to return West. Before leaving, he breaks off his relationship with Jordan Baker, who accuses him of being dishonest and a "bad driver." Nick later encounters Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue. Tom admits he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car, justifying his actions by saying Gatsby "had it coming to him" and had run over Myrtle without stopping. Nick concludes that Tom and Daisy are "careless people" who "smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness," leaving others to clean up their mess.

Nick visits Gatsby's empty house one last time, erasing an obscene word scrawled on the steps. He reflects on Gatsby's unattainable dream, symbolized by the green light, and the way the past ceaselessly pulls people back.

This summary details the plot of the provided text, "The Iliad," strictly based on the information within the given books and without external knowledge.

**Book I: The Contention of Achilles and Agamemnon**
The narrative begins in the tenth year of the siege of Troy. The Greeks have sacked neighboring towns and captured two beautiful women: Chryseïs, allotted to Agamemnon, and Briseïs, allotted to Achilles. Chryses, a priest of Apollo and father of Chryseïs, arrives at the Greek camp with gifts to ransom his daughter. Agamemnon insolently refuses and dismisses him. Chryses then prays to Apollo for vengeance. In response, Apollo inflicts a pestilence on the Greeks.

Achilles calls a council, encouraging the seer Chalcas to reveal the cause of the plague. Chalcas attributes it to Agamemnon's refusal to return Chryseïs. Agamemnon, enraged but compelled, agrees to send Chryseïs back. However, in an act of revenge, he seizes Briseïs from Achilles. This infuriates Achilles, who withdraws himself and his Myrmidon forces from the Greek army.

Achilles complains to his mother, the goddess Thetis, recounting the insult. Thetis, sympathetic to her son's plight, supplicates Jupiter to render the Greeks sensible of the wrong by granting victory to the Trojans. Jupiter, granting her request, incenses his wife Juno. A heated debate ensues between Jupiter and Juno, which is eventually pacified by their son, Vulcan. The events of this book span twenty-two days: nine during the plague, one for the council and quarrel, and twelve for Jupiter's absence with the Æthiopians before Thetis presents her petition.

**Book II: The Trial of the Army, and Catalogue of the Forces**
While the mortal leaders sleep, Jupiter, intent on honoring Achilles' request to bring woe upon the Greeks, sends a deceitful dream to Agamemnon. The dream, disguised as Nestor, persuades Agamemnon that he can conquer Troy immediately, as the gods have ceased their contention. Agamemnon is deluded by this vision and, upon waking, resolves to test the morale of his army.

He first consults his council of princes, revealing his plan to propose a return to Greece to the soldiers, expecting the chiefs to stop the resulting mass exodus. He then assembles the entire Greek host and delivers a speech suggesting they abandon the long, unsuccessful war and sail home. The disheartened Greek soldiers enthusiastically agree and rush to prepare their ships for departure.

Juno, seeing the Greeks about to abandon the siege, sends Pallas (Minerva) to prevent their flight. Minerva finds Ulysses, who is also distraught, and urges him to stop the retreat. Ulysses, taking Agamemnon's scepter, moves through the ranks. He uses persuasion and praise on the leaders, but uses physical force and harsh words to subdue common soldiers. He particularly chastises Thersites, a loud and ugly common soldier who openly criticizes Agamemnon and the war, striking him with the scepter.

The assembly is recalled. Ulysses delivers a speech, reminding them of an omen involving a serpent devouring a bird's nine offspring at Aulis nine years prior, interpreted by Chalcas as a sign that Troy would fall in the tenth year. Nestor then advises Agamemnon to organize the troops by their nations for battle. Agamemnon agrees, and the Greeks prepare for renewed combat.

The narrative then provides an extensive "Catalogue of the Ships," detailing all the Greek forces, their leaders, and their cities of origin. Meanwhile, Iris, sent by Jove, warns the Trojans of the Greek advance. She appears to Priam in the form of Polites and urges Hector to gather all his forces. The Trojans also assemble their army, which includes many auxiliary nations, and a "Catalogue of the Trojans" is provided, listing their leaders and lands.

**Book III: The Duel of Menelaus and Paris**
The armies advance, the Trojans with shouts and the Greeks silently. The beauteous Paris, prominent in the Trojan vanguard, challenges the bravest Greek to single combat. Menelaus, seeing Paris, eagerly leaps from his chariot to fight. Paris, however, shrinks back in fear and retreats into the Trojan ranks. Hector fiercely reproaches Paris for his cowardice, reminding him that his abduction of Helen caused the war.

Paris, stung by the rebuke, accepts the challenge and proposes a single combat between himself and Menelaus to decide the war, with Helen and her treasures as the prize. Hector conveys this proposal to the Greeks. Menelaus readily accepts, suggesting that King Priam should oversee the oaths due to the untrustworthiness of his sons.

Both armies agree and prepare for the duel. Iris, disguised as Laodice, goes to Helen, who is weaving her sad story into a golden tapestry. Iris tells Helen to witness the combat. Helen, moved by thoughts of Menelaus and her homeland, goes to the Scaean gate, where old Priam and the Trojan elders sit. Priam asks Helen to identify prominent Greek chiefs, and she points out Agamemnon, Ulysses, and Ajax. She laments the absence of her brothers, Castor and Pollux, unaware they are dead.

Heralds bring lambs for sacrifice. Priam and Agamemnon swear solemn oaths to the gods regarding the conditions of the duel. Priam then returns to Troy, unable to watch the fight. Hector and Ulysses mark the ground for the combat. Paris wins the lot to throw first.

The two heroes arm themselves. Paris throws his spear, which strikes Menelaus's shield but does not pierce it. Menelaus then throws his spear, piercing Paris's shield, corslet, and garment, but Paris dodges the final blow. Menelaus then draws his sword, which shatters on Paris's helmet. Menelaus seizes Paris by the helmet crest and begins to drag him. Venus intervenes unseen, breaks the helmet strap, and shrouds Paris in a cloud, transporting him safely to his apartment in Troy.

Menelaus, unable to find Paris, rages on the field. Venus, disguised, then fetches Helen from the Scaean gate and brings her to Paris, who is already in his room. Helen initially scolds Paris but, under threat from Venus, joins him. Agamemnon then declares Menelaus the victor and demands the return of Helen and the agreed-upon fine. The Greeks cheer in agreement.

**Book IV: The Breach of the Truce, and the First Battle**
The gods convene on Olympus. Jupiter, noting Venus's rescue of Paris, questions whether to continue the war or make peace. Juno, still fiercely determined to destroy Troy, angrily reminds him of her efforts and sacrifices. Jupiter reluctantly agrees to allow Troy's destruction in exchange for his future right to destroy Juno's favored cities. He sends Minerva to break the truce established for the duel.

Minerva, disguised as Laodocus, finds Pandarus among the Trojans and persuades him to shoot Menelaus with an arrow, promising him glory. Pandarus, using his polished bow, shoots an arrow. Minerva, however, diverts the arrow to only wound Menelaus in the belt, preventing a fatal injury. Agamemnon, seeing Menelaus bleed, expresses great distress and fears for the Greek army, but Menelaus assures him it's not a fatal wound. Machaon, the physician, is summoned and extracts the arrow, applying a soothing balm.

The Trojans, seeing Menelaus wounded and the truce broken, rush forward. Agamemnon moves through the Greek ranks, rallying his troops, praising the brave (like Idomeneus and the Ajaxes) and reproaching the timid. He particularly commends Nestor for his organized battle formations. He also reproves Ulysses and Diomed for their initial hesitation, who then rejoin the fight with renewed vigor.

The battle joins with immense clamor. Antilochus kills Echepolus, but Elephenor is killed trying to strip him. Ajax kills Simoisius. Ulysses kills Democoon, causing a temporary Trojan retreat. Apollo then rallies the Trojans, reminding them that Achilles is not fighting. The battle resumes fiercely, with many heroes falling on both sides, including Diores (killed by Pyrus) and Pyrus (killed by Thoas). The field becomes a scene of widespread slaughter.

**Book V: The Acts of Diomed**
Minerva inspires Diomed, making him shine with divine fire and rage through the battle. He kills Phegeus and then Idæus (who is saved by Vulcan). Minerva then persuades Mars to withdraw from the field. Diomed continues his rampage, killing Odius, Phæstus, Scamandrius, Phereclus, Pedaeus, and Hypsenor.

Pandarus wounds Diomed with an arrow from afar, but the wound is superficial. Diomed retreats to his chariot, where Sthenelus extracts the arrow. Diomed prays to Pallas, who heals him, gives him the ability to discern gods from mortals, and instructs him to attack only Venus if she enters the fight.

Diomed returns to battle with renewed fury, killing Astynous, Hypenor, Abas, Polyidus, Xanthus, and Thoon. Æneas, seeing Diomed's prowess, persuades Pandarus to join him in his chariot against Diomed. Sthenelus warns Diomed of their approach, but Diomed refuses to retreat and instructs Sthenelus to seize Æneas's immortal horses if he falls.

Pandarus throws his spear, which strikes Diomed's shield but does not pierce it. Diomed then throws his spear, guided by Pallas, killing Pandarus by piercing his face. Æneas attempts to protect Pandarus's body, but Diomed throws a massive stone, gravely wounding Æneas in the hip. Venus, seeing her son, rescues him by covering him with her veil. Diomed, recognizing Venus, pursues and wounds her hand with his spear. Venus, shrieking, drops Æneas and flees to Olympus, where she complains to Jove. Jove tells her to leave war to Mars and Pallas. Apollo then rescues Æneas, carrying him to Troy for healing, and creates a phantom of Æneas to rally the Trojans.

Sarpedon reproaches Hector for his inaction, spurring him to rally the Trojans. Hector, spurred, charges back into battle with Mars by his side. Diomed, seeing Mars, advises the Greeks to retreat slowly. Hector then kills Anchialus and Mnesthes. Ajax kills Amphius. Tlepolemus challenges Sarpedon. They duel, and Tlepolemus kills Sarpedon's horse Pedasus. Sarpedon kills Tlepolemus with a spear, but Jove saves his son from immediate death. Ulysses avenges Tlepolemus by killing several Lycians.

A fierce battle rages over Sarpedon's body. Glaucus, wounded earlier, prays to Apollo for healing, which is granted. He then rallies the Trojans and Hector to defend Sarpedon's body. Jove, to honor Sarpedon, covers the field in darkness. The Greeks eventually secure Sarpedon's armor, and Patroclus takes it. Jove commands Apollo to retrieve Sarpedon's body, cleanse it, anoint it, and have Sleep and Death carry it to Lycia for proper burial.

Juno and Minerva descend to resist Mars. Minerva incites Diomed, who, with Pallas's aid, wounds Mars in the groin. Mars bellows in pain and flees to Olympus, where he complains to Jove. Jove rebukes Mars for his warlike nature but has Pæon heal him. Juno and Pallas return to Olympus.

**Book VI: The Episodes of Glaucus and Diomed, and of Hector and Andromache**
With the gods withdrawing, the Greeks begin to prevail. Ajax kills Acamas. Diomed kills Axylus and his servant Calesius. Euryalus kills Dresus and the twin sons of Bucolion. Polypoetes kills Astyalus. Ulysses kills Pidytes. Teucer kills Aretaon. Nestor's son kills Ablerus. Agamemnon kills Elatus. Eurypylus kills Melanthius.

Menelaus captures Adrastus, who pleads for mercy and offers ransom. Agamemnon, however, intervenes and ruthlessly kills Adrastus, demanding no Trojan be spared. Nestor urges the Greeks to continue fighting rather than stripping the dead.

Helenus, a Trojan augur, advises Hector to rally the Trojans and then return to the city to instruct his mother Hecuba and the Trojan matrons to offer prayers and gifts (a robe and twelve heifers) to Minerva, hoping to appease her and stop Diomed's rampage. Hector, after rallying his troops, leaves for Troy.

Meanwhile, Glaucus and Diomed meet between the armies. Diomed questions Glaucus's identity, stating he avoids fighting gods. Glaucus recounts his illustrious mortal lineage, tracing back to Sisyphus and Bellerophon, who performed heroic deeds in Lycia. Diomed then realizes that their grandfathers, Oeneus and Bellerophon, were guest-friends. To honor this ancestral bond, they agree not to fight each other and exchange armor. Glaucus exchanges his golden armor for Diomed's brass armor, a less valuable exchange.

Hector arrives at the Scaean Gate in Troy, where women and elders question him. He instructs Hecuba about the offerings to Minerva. Hecuba and the matrons proceed to Minerva's temple, lay a veil before the goddess, and pray for her mercy, but Minerva denies their prayers.

Hector then goes to Paris's house, finding him polishing his armor with Helen and her handmaids nearby. Hector sternly reproaches Paris for his idleness. Paris accepts the rebuke, stating he was lost in grief but is now ready to return to battle. Helen expresses self-blame for the war and her wish for death.

Hector refuses Helen's offer for him to rest. He seeks his wife Andromache and their son Astyanax at the Scaean Gate. Andromache tearfully pleads with him not to return to battle, fearing he will die and leave her and their son helpless. She suggests he defend the walls from a safer position. Hector explains that honor and duty compel him to fight, as he cannot bear the shame of avoiding battle, especially knowing Troy's eventual fall and Andromache's impending enslavement. He then embraces and blesses his son, praying for him to become a renowned warrior. Andromache, grieving, returns home. Hector and Paris, now fully armed and eager, return to the battlefield.

**Book VII: The Single Combat of Hector and Ajax**
Hector and Paris return to the battle, reinvigorating the Trojan forces. Hector kills Eioneus, Paris kills Menestheus, and Glaucus kills Iphinous. Minerva, seeing the renewed Trojan success, descends from Olympus. Apollo meets her near the Scaean Gate, and they agree to halt the general battle for the day. Helenus, the Trojan seer, divining the gods' will, advises Hector to challenge the bravest Greek to a single combat.

Hector issues the challenge, proposing that the victor take the loser's armor, but return the body for proper burial. The Greeks are initially silent and afraid. Menelaus, shamed, volunteers but is restrained by Agamemnon, who reminds him of Hector's superior strength. Nestor then rebukes the Greeks for their cowardice and recounts his own youthful prowess. Nine Greek chiefs, including Diomed, the two Ajaxes, Idomeneus, Meriones, Eurypylus, Thoas, and Ulysses, then volunteer.

Lots are cast to decide who will fight Hector, and the lot falls upon Ajax Telamon. Ajax rejoices, arms himself, and steps forward to meet Hector. They exchange boasts. Hector throws his spear first, striking Ajax's seven-layered shield but failing to pierce it. Ajax then throws his spear, piercing Hector's shield and corslet, but Hector manages to avoid a fatal blow. They then close in fierce combat, exchanging blows with stones. Hector hurls a large stone at Ajax's shield, and Ajax hurls an even larger one, striking Hector and knocking him down, though Apollo revives him.

As they are about to draw swords for closer combat, the heralds Idæus (Trojan) and Talthybius (Greek) intervene, stopping the fight due to nightfall. Hector and Ajax, respecting the truce, exchange gifts: Hector gives Ajax a silver-studded sword, and Ajax gives Hector a purple belt. They then return to their respective armies.

The Greeks hold a council. Nestor advises them to burn their dead and, to protect their fleet, build a strong fortification of a wall, deep trench, gates, and palisades around their camp. At Troy, Priam calls a council. Antenor proposes returning Helen and her treasures to the Greeks to end the war, but Paris refuses to return Helen, only offering her treasures. Priam then proposes sending a herald to the Greeks with Paris's offer and requesting a truce for burning the dead.

The next morning, Idæus presents the offer to the Greeks. Diomed vehemently rejects Paris's wealth and Helen, asserting that Troy is destined to fall. The Greeks acclaim his words. Agamemnon accepts only the truce for burial. Both armies then gather and burn their dead. Afterwards, the Greeks build their proposed fortification. Neptune is angered that the Greeks built a wall without consulting the gods, but Jupiter assures him that he will destroy it after the war. Both armies feast through the night, but Jove sends thunder and lightning, disheartening the Trojans.

**Book VIII: The Second Battle, and the Distress of the Greeks**
At dawn, Jupiter convenes a council of the gods on Olympus. He forbids any deity from intervening in the battle, threatening to cast anyone who disobeys into Tartarus and demonstrating his supreme power by claiming he could lift the entire world with his golden chain. Minerva obtains permission to at least offer counsel to the Greeks.

Jupiter then travels to Mount Ida and, from there, weighs the fates of Greece and Troy in his golden scales; the Greek side sinks. He sends thunder and lightning, striking terror into the Greeks and forcing them to retreat. Nestor's horse is wounded by Paris, leaving the old hero vulnerable. Diomed rescues Nestor, calling to Ulysses who flees to the ships. Diomed takes Nestor into his chariot (pulled by Æneas's captured horses) and confronts Hector. Diomed throws his spear, missing Hector but killing his charioteer, Eniopeus. Hector appoints Archeptolemus as his new charioteer. As Diomed attempts another attack, Jove sends a lightning bolt in front of his chariot, forcing him and Nestor to retreat. Hector pursues them, mocking Diomed.

Hector boasts of his impending victory and plans to burn the Greek ships that night. Juno, distressed, urges Neptune to intervene, but Neptune refuses to defy Jove. Hector then leads the Trojans, driving the Greeks back through their trench and behind their new wall. Agamemnon, distraught, rallies his troops with a prayer to Jove. Jove, moved, sends an eagle with a fawn as an omen, encouraging the Greeks.

The Greeks rally. Diomed charges first, killing Agelaus, followed by the Atridae, Ajaxes, Idomeneus, Meriones, and Teucer. Teucer, protected by Ajax's shield, kills several Trojans with his arrows. Agamemnon praises Teucer and promises him rewards. Teucer aims at Hector twice, missing him but killing other Trojan chiefs. Hector, enraged, throws a stone at Teucer, breaking his bowstring and disabling him. Ajax shields Teucer, who is carried off.

The Trojans, re-energized, push the Greeks back towards their ships. Juno and Minerva again prepare to intervene, but Jove sends Iris to warn them of severe punishment if they defy him. The goddesses reluctantly retreat. Jupiter returns to Olympus, rebukes Juno and Minerva, and reaffirms his plan: Hector will continue to win until Patroclus is slain, after which Achilles will rise and Hector will fall, leading to Troy's destruction.

Night falls, ending the battle. The Trojans, victorious, decide to camp on the plain outside the Greek fortifications, lighting numerous fires to prevent the Greeks from escaping by sea. Hector commands them to forage, refresh, and maintain watch, boasting that they will crush the Greeks at dawn and burn their fleet.

**Book IX: The Embassy to Achilles**
The Greeks are overcome with fear and despair after their defeat. Agamemnon, weeping, calls a council and proposes abandoning the siege and returning home. Diomed fiercely opposes this, condemning Agamemnon's cowardice and declaring he will stay and fight alone if necessary. Nestor praises Diomed's spirit and advises Agamemnon to call a council of elders.

In the council, Nestor suggests sending an embassy to Achilles to appease his wrath. Agamemnon agrees, offering an immense array of gifts: ten talents of gold, twenty shining vases, seven tripods, twelve prize-winning horses, seven beautiful Lesbian captives (including Briseïs, whom he solemnly swears he never touched), and promises more riches, one of his daughters in marriage, and seven wealthy cities after Troy's fall.

Nestor selects Phoenix, Ajax, and Ulysses as ambassadors, accompanied by heralds. They journey to Achilles' tent, where they find him playing the lyre with Patroclus. Achilles welcomes them warmly and offers them a feast. After the meal, Ulysses delivers Agamemnon's offer and passionately pleads for Achilles to return to battle, emphasizing the dire state of the Greeks and Hector's rampage.

Achilles, however, remains unyielding. He fiercely rejects Agamemnon's gifts and reconciliation, expressing his deep-seated hatred for the king's deceit and pride. He recounts his unrewarded labors and declares his intention to sail home to Phthia in three days. He reiterates his mother Thetis's prophecy that he faces a choice between a short, glorious life at Troy or a long, inglorious life at home, and says he now chooses the latter. He advises the Greeks to do the same. Achilles tells Phoenix he can stay with him.

Phoenix, weeping, recounts his own past as an exile taken in by Peleus, Achilles' father, and how he raised Achilles. He urges Achilles to temper his rage and recalls the story of Meleager, who refused to fight for his city until it was nearly overwhelmed, ultimately fighting for lesser rewards. Achilles thanks Phoenix but still refuses, stating he will not fight until Hector's forces reach his own ships and threaten them with fire.

Ajax then directly scolds Achilles, criticizing him for his stubbornness over a single woman when greater wrongs are often forgiven. Achilles replies that his rage is still too great. The ambassadors return to Agamemnon's tent. Ulysses reports Achilles' firm refusal. Diomed advises against further attempts to persuade Achilles and urges the Greeks to prepare for battle at dawn, with Agamemnon leading. The Greeks then take refreshment and sleep.

**Book X: The Night-Adventure of Diomed and Ulysses**
Agamemnon, consumed by anxiety over the Trojan fires and the dire situation of the Greeks, cannot sleep. He rises, arms himself, and decides to consult Nestor. Menelaus, also sleepless, meets him, and they agree to wake other key chiefs. Agamemnon goes to Nestor, finding him awake and armed. Nestor agrees to call a council and suggests waking Ulysses, Diomed, Meges, and Ajax the Lesser. He also sends others to wake Ajax the Greater and Idomeneus.

Nestor then wakes Ulysses and Diomed. They gather at the Greek fortifications with the other chiefs and guards. Nestor proposes a dangerous spy mission into the Trojan camp to gather intelligence. Diomed volunteers and chooses Ulysses as his companion, praising his wisdom and Pallas's favor. They arm themselves, and Minerva sends a heron as a good omen.

Meanwhile, Hector holds a council, offering Achilles' chariot and immortal horses as a reward to any Trojan who will spy on the Greek camp. Dolon, a swift but unattractive Trojan, volunteers, extracting a promise from Hector. He sets out dressed in a wolf's hide.

Ulysses and Diomed spot Dolon. They let him pass, then ambush and capture him. Dolon, terrified, begs for his life and reveals Hector's plans and the disposition of the Trojan and auxiliary forces, including the newly arrived Thracian king Rhesus and his splendid white horses. Diomed, having extracted the information, kills Dolon, preventing his future espionage. They hang Dolon's spoils on a tree as an offering to Pallas.

Diomed and Ulysses proceed to the Thracian camp. Ulysses spots Rhesus's horses and signals Diomed. Diomed, inspired by Pallas, slaughters Rhesus and twelve of his men in their sleep. Ulysses drags the bodies away and leads the immortal horses back. Pallas appears to Diomed, urging him to return. They swiftly ride back to the Greek camp, where Nestor recognizes them by the sound of the horses. Ulysses recounts their successful mission. The Thracian horses are brought to Diomed's stalls, and the heroes cleanse themselves and offer libations to Pallas.

**Book XI: The Third Battle, and the Acts of Agamemnon**
At dawn, Eris (Discord), sent by Jove, descends to the Greek fleet, inciting a fierce battle. Agamemnon, fully armed in magnificent divine armor, leads the Greeks. Juno and Pallas encourage them. Jove, observing, sends red drops of blood as a grim omen. The Trojans, led by Hector, Polydamas, and Æneas, also advance.

The battle rages fiercely and equally in the morning. Agamemnon then unleashes a powerful rampage, killing Bienor, Oïleus, two sons of Priam (Isus and Antiphus), and the treacherous sons of Antimachus, refusing their pleas for ransom. He drives the Trojans back towards their city walls.

Jove sends Iris to Hector, instructing him to retreat from the front while Agamemnon is raging, but to return to battle when Agamemnon is wounded and withdraws. Hector obeys. Agamemnon kills Iphidamas, who wounds him in the arm. Coon, Iphidamas's brother, then wounds Agamemnon in the arm. Agamemnon, despite his wound, kills Coon. However, the pain of his wound forces Agamemnon to retreat to the ships, exhorting his troops to fight on.

Seeing Agamemnon withdraw, Hector, with renewed vigor, rallies the Trojans and charges, killing many Greeks. Ulysses and Diomed stand together to resist him, killing Thymbraeus and Molion, and then the sons of Merops and Agastrophus. Paris, from behind a monument, shoots Diomed in the foot with an arrow. Diomed, though dismissive of the wound, is forced to retreat, with Ulysses extracting the arrow.

Ulysses, now isolated, is surrounded by Trojans. He fights bravely, killing several, but is wounded by Socus. Ulysses kills Socus in return but is hard-pressed and calls for help. Menelaus hears his cry and brings Ajax to his rescue. They drive off the Trojans and carry the wounded Ulysses to his chariot. Ajax continues fighting.

Hector, elsewhere on the field, continues his slaughter. Paris wounds Machaon, the physician, with an arrow. Idomeneus tells Nestor to convey Machaon to the ships for treatment. Nestor takes Machaon in his chariot. Hector's charioteer, Cebriones, points out Ajax's continued resistance. Hector turns to confront Ajax, but Jove strikes Ajax with fear, forcing him to slowly retreat. Eurypylus tries to help Ajax but is wounded by an arrow from Paris.

Patroclus, having seen Machaon taken from the field, asks Achilles about the wounded warrior. Achilles sends him to Nestor's tent to inquire. Nestor, in his tent, recounts the numerous Greek losses and passionately laments Achilles' absence. He urges Patroclus to persuade Achilles to fight, or at least to lead the Myrmidons himself, clad in Achilles' armor, to frighten the Trojans. Patroclus is moved and, on his return, encounters the wounded Eurypylus. He takes Eurypylus to his tent and tends to his wound.

**Book XII: The Battle at the Grecian Wall**
The Greeks have been driven back behind their newly constructed wall and trench. The text mentions that this wall, built without proper sacrifices, is destined to be destroyed by Neptune and Apollo after the war. Hector, fierce as a wild beast, leads the Trojans towards the wall. The Trojan horses hesitate at the deep trench, which is filled with sharpened stakes.

Polydamas advises Hector to abandon their chariots and attack the wall on foot, dividing their army into five battalions. Hector agrees and his troops dismount. Asius, however, ignores this advice and drives his chariot directly to one of the gates. He is bravely repelled by two Lapith chiefs, Polypoetes and Leonteus, who fight like mighty trees. Asius, frustrated, complains to Jove about his ill fortune.

Meanwhile, an omen appears: an eagle carrying a serpent. The serpent wounds the eagle, which drops its prey among the Trojans and flies away. Polydamas interprets this as a sign that they will breach the wall but suffer heavy losses and fail to capture the ships, and advises retreat. Hector furiously rejects this, asserting his faith in Jove's command for victory and threatening any who disobey.

Hector then leads the assault on the wall. Jove aids the Trojans with a whirlwind. The Trojans undermine the wall and pull down the palisades. Sarpedon, inspired by Jove, makes the first breach, tearing away stones from the rampart. Teucer wounds Glaucus in the arm, forcing him to retreat. Sarpedon kills Alcmaon and continues his rampage. Ajax wounds Sarpedon, but Jove protects his son. Sarpedon rallies his Lycians to press the attack. Hector, with Jove's aid, hurls a massive stone at the gates, shattering them. The Trojans pour through the breach and rush into the Greek camp towards the ships.

**Book XIII: The Fourth Battle Continued, in Which Neptune Assists the Greeks; The Acts of Idomeneus**
Jove, having granted the Trojans success, turns his attention away from the battlefield, leaving the combatants to their fate. Neptune, observing the Greek's distress and Jove's absence, rises from the sea. Disguised as Calchas, he inspires the Ajaxes and other Greek chiefs, filling them with renewed strength and urging them to make a stand against Hector. The Greeks rally and form a tight phalanx.

Hector continues his charge. Meriones throws a spear at Deiphobus, but it breaks. Teucer kills Imbrius, and Hector, aiming for Teucer, kills Amphimachus instead. Ajax and Teucer strip the bodies, and Ajax lops off Imbrius's head, throwing it towards Hector. Neptune, enraged by Amphimachus's death, appears to Idomeneus, disguised as Thoas, and urges him to join the fight. Idomeneus, after retrieving a new spear from his tent, returns to battle with Meriones.

Idomeneus kills Othryoneus, a Trojan who had come to Troy seeking Cassandra's hand. He then kills Asius and his charioteer. Deiphobus attacks Idomeneus, missing him but killing Hypsenor. Idomeneus then kills Alcathous, Anchises' son-in-law. Deiphobus, grieving, calls Æneas to help him avenge Alcathous. Æneas, who had been holding back due to a slight from Priam, is moved and joins the fight against Idomeneus. A fierce struggle erupts over Alcathous's body.

Idomeneus kills OEnomas. Deiphobus wounds Ascalaphus. Meriones wounds Deiphobus in the arm, and Polites helps him retreat. Æneas kills Aphareus, and Antilochus kills Thoon. Meriones wounds Adamas. Helenus wounds Deipyrus. Menelaus wounds Helenus in the hand with a spear and kills Pisander with his sword. Paris kills Harpalion with an arrow, and Meriones finishes him. Paris then wounds Euchenor with an arrow.

Hector remains fixed in the center, where the Greek wall was breached. The Locrian archers, led by Ajax the Lesser, provide covering fire. Polydamas, seeing the Trojans struggling, advises Hector to call a council and consider retreating to the city. Hector, after some initial hesitation, agrees to rally his chiefs. He reproaches Paris for his idleness, who then returns to the thickest fight with Hector. They regroup and charge, but Ajax confronts Hector, defying him and blaming Jove for the Greek's distress. The book ends with their exchange of challenges, the armies in a stand-off.

**Book XIV: Juno Deceives Jupiter by the Girdle of Venus**
Nestor, hearing the increasing clamor from the battle, leaves the wounded Machaon in his tent and goes to investigate. He sees the Greek wall in ruins and the army in flight. He meets Agamemnon, Ulysses, and Diomed, who are all wounded. Agamemnon, in despair, proposes abandoning the siege and sailing home under cover of night. Ulysses fiercely rejects this, shaming Agamemnon for such a cowardly suggestion. Diomed advises that even though wounded, the kings should return to the front to encourage the troops, staying out of direct combat. The kings agree.

Neptune, seeing the distressed Greeks, appears disguised as an old warrior, encourages Agamemnon, and gives a powerful shout that rallies the Greek spirit. Meanwhile, Juno, high on Olympus, sees Neptune aiding the Greeks and Jove on Mount Ida. To distract Jove, she decides to seduce him. She adorns herself beautifully, anointing herself with ambrosial oils, braiding her hair, donning a magnificent mantle, and glittering jewels. She then goes to Venus and, under false pretenses (claiming she needs to reconcile Ocean and Tethys), obtains Venus's magic girdle (cestus), which holds irresistible charms of love and desire.

Juno then flies to Lemnos to seek Sleep. She asks him to put Jove to sleep, offering Pasithaë, one of the Graces, as his wife. Sleep initially refuses, recalling Jove's wrath when he put him to sleep for Hercules, but with Juno's oath and the promise of Pasithaë, he agrees. Juno and Sleep go to Mount Ida, where Sleep hides disguised as a bird. Juno seduces Jove, who, overwhelmed by her charms, makes love to her. Jove falls into a deep sleep.

Sleep immediately flies to Neptune, informing him that Jove is asleep, giving Neptune free rein to aid the Greeks. Neptune, filled with zeal, rallies the Greeks, urging them to fight with strong resolve. The wounded kings, including Agamemnon, assist in reorganizing the troops.

The battle intensifies. Hector throws his spear at Ajax, but it is blocked. Ajax then hurls a massive stone at Hector, striking him in the chest and knocking him unconscious. Hector falls, his armor clanking. Polydamas, Agenor, and Æneas quickly shield Hector and carry him off the field, where his chariot takes him back towards Troy. With Hector removed, the Greeks fiercely attack. Ajax the Lesser kills Satnius. Polydamas kills Prothoënor. Ajax kills Archilochus. Acamas kills Promachus. Peneleus kills Ilioneus and holds up his severed head to taunt the Trojans. Meriones kills Hyperenor. Ajax the Lesser leads a furious pursuit of the retreating Trojans.

**Book XV: The Fifth Battle at the Ships; and the Acts of Ajax**
The Trojans are in full retreat. Jupiter awakens on Mount Ida and sees the Greek success, Hector wounded, and Neptune leading the Greeks. He is furious with Juno, accusing her of deception and reminding her of past punishments. Juno, trembling, denies responsibility and swears by Styx that Neptune acted on his own initiative.

Jupiter accepts her denial and reveals his unalterable plan: Juno must send Iris to command Neptune to withdraw from the battle, and Apollo to heal Hector and re-inspire the Trojans. Hector will then drive the Greeks back to their ships, Patroclus will be slain, Achilles will return to battle, and Hector will then die, leading to Troy's fall.

Juno flies to Olympus and, in the assembly of the gods, complains about Jove's tyrannical nature, inciting Mars. Mars, enraged by the death of his son Ascalaphus, prepares to fight, but Minerva restrains him, reminding him of Jove's power. Juno then sends Iris to Neptune and Apollo to Hector. Iris delivers Jove's command to Neptune, who, after expressing indignation at Jove's perceived arrogance, reluctantly withdraws from the battle and plunges into the sea.

Jove then sends Apollo to Hector. Apollo finds Hector still unconscious and revives him, filling him with strength and valor. Hector, revitalized, returns to battle, with Apollo leading him and bearing Jove's fearsome ægis. The Greeks are struck with terror and flee. Hector leads a new rampage, killing many Greeks. Apollo easily destroys the Greek wall and fills the trench, creating a clear path for the Trojans to the ships.

Nestor, in despair, prays to Jove to save the fleet. Jove responds with thunder, which the Trojans misinterpret as a sign of success. The Trojans, led by Hector, storm the Greek ships, attempting to set them on fire. Patroclus, still tending to Eurypylus, sees the imminent danger to the fleet and rushes to Achilles to urge him to fight. Ajax the Greater fights valiantly on the ships, killing Clytius, who attempted to light a ship on fire, and then Lycophron. Teucer aims an arrow at Hector, but Jove breaks his bowstring. Ajax tells Teucer to switch to a spear and shield. Hector encourages the Trojans, boasting of Jove's favor. Ajax rallies the Greeks, urging them to defend their last stand. The battle rages intensely at the ships. Hector reaches Protesilaus's ship, grasping its stern and calling for fire. Ajax makes a desperate stand, killing twelve Trojans who attempt to light the ships.

**Book XVI: The Sixth Battle, the Acts and Death of Patroclus**
Patroclus, weeping, approaches Achilles, recounting the severe Greek losses and the burning ships. He begs Achilles to fight or, failing that, to allow him to lead the Myrmidons into battle, clad in Achilles' armor, to frighten the Trojans and save the fleet. Achilles is moved and agrees, but gives a strict warning: Patroclus must only drive the Trojans from the ships and not pursue them to the city walls, as Hector is Achilles' destined foe. He expresses a fervent wish that all Greeks and Trojans might perish, leaving only him and Patroclus to take Troy.

Patroclus dons Achilles' armor (except for his Pelian ash spear). Automedon harnesses Achilles' immortal horses, Xanthus and Balius, along with the mortal Pedasus. Achilles rallies his Myrmidon forces, dividing them under five leaders. Achilles then pours a libation to Jove, praying for Patroclus's success in saving the ships and for his safe return. Jove grants the former but not the latter. Achilles then retires to his tent to watch.

Ajax, overwhelmed by the Trojan assault and the firebrands, is forced to retreat from the ships. Patroclus and the Myrmidons charge, and the Trojans, mistaking Patroclus for Achilles, are struck with panic and flee. Patroclus extinguishes the fires and drives the Trojans back. The Greeks rally and kill many Trojans. Patroclus kills Areilycus, Thoas, and Amphidus. Antilochus kills Atymnius and Maris. Peneleus kills Cleobulus and Lycon. Merion kills Neamas and Erymas.

Sarpedon, seeing his Lycian forces routed, reproaches them and challenges Patroclus. Jove, foreseeing his son Sarpedon's death, debates whether to save him, but Juno persuades him that fate must run its course. Jove, grieving, sends a shower of blood over the field. Patroclus and Sarpedon engage in single combat. Patroclus's spear kills Thrasymed. Sarpedon's spear misses Patroclus but kills Pedasus, one of Achilles' immortal horses. Automedon swiftly cuts the harness to free the remaining horses. Patroclus then throws his spear, piercing Sarpedon's heart and killing him. Sarpedon's dying words are an appeal to Glaucus to defend his body. Glaucus, wounded earlier, prays to Apollo for healing, which is granted, and he then rallies the Trojans and Hector to recover Sarpedon's body.

A fierce battle erupts over Sarpedon's body. Jove covers the field in darkness. Hector kills Epigeus, and Patroclus kills Sthenelaus. Glaucus kills Bathyclaeus, and Merion kills Laogonus. The Greeks eventually prevail, securing Sarpedon's body and Achilles' armor. Patroclus takes the armor as spoils. Jove commands Apollo to retrieve Sarpedon's body, cleanse it, anoint it, and have Sleep and Death transport it to Lycia for burial.

Patroclus, flush with victory and disregarding Achilles' warning, pursues the fleeing Trojans to the walls of Troy. Thrice he attempts to scale the walls, and thrice Apollo repulses him, warning him that Troy is not destined to fall by his hand. Apollo, disguised as Asius, encourages Hector to attack Patroclus. Hector, dismounted, confronts Patroclus. Patroclus kills Cebriones, Hector's charioteer, with a stone.

A battle ensues over Cebriones' body. Apollo, hidden in a cloud, strikes Patroclus from behind, causing his helmet to fall, his spear to break, his shield to drop, and his armor to loosen. Euphorbus, a Dardan youth, then wounds Patroclus in the back with a spear and retreats. Hector, seeing Patroclus disarmed and wounded, rushes in and stabs him with his lance, delivering a mortal blow. Hector boasts over the dying Patroclus. Patroclus, with his dying breath, prophesies Hector's imminent death at Achilles' hands. Hector then pulls his spear from Patroclus's body and, after a brief chase, strips Achilles' armor from the dead Patroclus.

**Book XVII: The Seventh Battle, for the Body of Patroclus.—The Acts of Menelaus**
Upon Patroclus's death, Menelaus immediately springs to defend his body from the Trojans. Euphorbus, who wounded Patroclus, challenges Menelaus for the spoils. Menelaus scorns his boast and kills Euphorbus with a spear to the throat, stripping his armor. Apollo, disguised as Mentes, advises Hector to abandon his pursuit of Achilles' horses and instead challenge Menelaus for Patroclus's body.

Hector, seeing Euphorbus dead and Menelaus with his armor, charges. Menelaus, seeing Hector and his forces, reluctantly retreats and calls for Ajax. Ajax arrives and covers Patroclus's body with his great shield. Hector, seeing Ajax, retreats with Achilles' armor (which he had taken from Patroclus).

Glaucus fiercely reproaches Hector for his cowardice and for abandoning Sarpedon's body, threatening that the Lycians will no longer fight for Troy if he continues to show such weakness. He urges Hector to fight for Patroclus's body to exchange it for Sarpedon's. Hector, stung by the rebuke, denies cowardice and declares he will prove his valor. He puts on Achilles' armor, promising equal honors and spoils to any Trojan who helps him claim Patroclus's body. Jove, seeing Hector in Achilles' divine armor, pities Hector's destined short life but grants him strength for one more day of glory.

The battle for Patroclus's body intensifies. Hector, imbued with divine strength, rallies the Trojans. Ajax rallies the Greeks. Hippothous attempts to drag Patroclus's body away by his ankles but is killed by Ajax. Schedius and Phorcys are also killed. Apollo, disguised as Periphas, inspires Æneas to rally the Trojans. Æneas charges, killing Leocritus. Lycomedes kills Apisaon.

Jove shrouds the battle around Patroclus's body in darkness, while the rest of the field is in sunshine. Achilles' immortal horses, Xanthus and Balius, stand weeping over Patroclus's death, inconsolable despite Automedon's efforts. Jove pities them and grants them renewed spirit. Automedon asks Alcimedon to drive the chariot while he fights on foot. Hector and Æneas charge to seize Achilles' chariot. Automedon fights bravely, killing Aretus. The Ajaxes intervene, and Hector and Æneas are driven back.

Minerva, sent by Jove, inspires Menelaus, who kills Podes, a friend of Hector. Apollo, disguised as Phaenops, informs Hector of Podes' death, spurring Hector to attack Menelaus. Jove shakes his ægis, spreading fear among the Greeks. Peneleus and Leitus are wounded. Idomeneus throws a spear at Hector, which breaks. Hector kills Coeranus, Meriones' charioteer. Meriones and Idomeneus retreat.

Ajax, seeing the Greek's dire situation and the darkness Jove has cast, prays to Jove to dispel the cloud, wishing to die in daylight if it is their fate. Jove grants light. Ajax then tells Menelaus to find Antilochus and send him to Achilles with the news of Patroclus's death. Menelaus and Meriones then lift Patroclus's body, while the two Ajaxes cover their retreat, fighting fiercely. Antilochus, weeping, runs to Achilles to deliver the devastating news. The Trojans furiously pursue the Greeks carrying Patroclus's body, but the Ajaxes bravely defend the rear, allowing the body to be borne to the ships.

**Book XVIII: The Grief of Achilles, and New Armour Made Him by Vulcan**
Achilles, seated by his ship, feels a grim foreboding of Patroclus's death. Antilochus arrives, weeping, and confirms the terrible news: Patroclus is dead, and Hector has stripped him of Achilles' armor. Achilles is overcome with profound grief, spreading ashes on his head, tearing his hair, and groveling in the dust. The captive women lament with him. Antilochus holds him to prevent self-harm.

Thetis, from her deep-sea cave, hears Achilles' cries. She and her Nereid sisters rise to comfort him. Thetis laments her son's short, sorrowful life and his inevitable death. Achilles declares he has no desire to live unless he can kill Hector and avenge Patroclus, accepting his own impending death. Thetis promises to bring him new, divine armor forged by Vulcan by dawn. She then dismisses her Nereids and ascends to Olympus.

Meanwhile, the Greeks are still struggling to recover Patroclus's body from the furious Trojans. Hector, like a flame, rages over the field. Juno, seeing the Greeks in distress, sends Iris to Achilles (without Jove's knowledge) to urge him to show himself at the trench. Achilles explains he is unarmed. Iris tells him to simply appear, as his presence alone will terrify the Trojans. Achilles rises. Pallas throws her ægis over his shoulders and crowns his head with a golden cloud, from which fire blazes. Achilles shouts from the trench, and Minerva amplifies his voice. The Trojans are struck with terror, their horses recoil, and many are crushed. The Greeks seize the opportunity and finally retrieve Patroclus's body. Achilles then mourns over his dead friend.

Juno commands the sun to set, ending the battle and bringing relief to the weary Greeks. The frightened Trojans hold a council. Polydamas advises retreating inside the city walls, fearing Achilles' return. Hector furiously rejects this, insisting they stay on the plain to face Achilles at dawn and boasting of his own readiness. Pallas influences the Trojans to applaud Hector's bad advice.

Achilles continues to mourn Patroclus through the night, embracing his body and vowing to avenge him by killing Hector and sacrificing twelve Trojan youths on his pyre. He orders his men to wash and prepare Patroclus's body. Thetis arrives at Vulcan's forge on Olympus. Vulcan expresses gratitude to Thetis for past kindness and promises to forge magnificent new armor for Achilles.

Vulcan creates an immense, elaborately decorated shield. Its surface depicts: the cosmos (earth, heaven, sun, moon, stars); two cities, one in peace (weddings, feasts, justice) and one in war (siege, ambush, battle); a ploughed field; a king's harvest; a vineyard; a herd of cattle attacked by lions; a flock of sheep; and a dancing floor. He also forges a cuirass, greaves, and a helmet. Thetis takes the blazing armor and flies back to Achilles.

**Book XIX: The Reconciliation of Achilles and Agamemnon**
At dawn, Thetis brings the new, divine armor from Vulcan to Achilles, finding him still weeping over Patroclus's body. The armor blazes with fire, filling Achilles with rage and desire for battle. Achilles expresses concern that Patroclus's body will decay, but Thetis reassures him, pouring nectar and ambrosia into the corpse to preserve it from corruption.

Achilles, obeying his mother, calls the Greeks to assembly. He publicly declares an end to his quarrel with Agamemnon, stating that their strife has caused too much suffering, and he is eager to fight. Agamemnon accepts Achilles' renunciation, blaming Jove, Fate, and the goddess Ate for his past actions. He repeats his offer of gifts and solemnly swears an oath that he never touched Briseïs.

Achilles dismisses the gifts, eager for immediate battle. Ulysses, however, advises that the army first eat and rest to restore their strength for the coming combat. He insists that Agamemnon formally present the gifts and swear his oath in public, to set a good example. Agamemnon agrees to all of Ulysses's suggestions.

Ulysses and other chiefs bring the gifts from Agamemnon's tent to Achilles' tent. Agamemnon, holding a boar for sacrifice, publicly swears his oath. The boar is then thrown into the sea. The Greeks are urged to eat, but Achilles, consumed by grief, refuses all food, vowing not to eat until he has avenged Patroclus. Jove, seeing Achilles' fasting, sends Minerva to infuse ambrosia and nectar into his breast, strengthening him without food.

Achilles then arms himself in his new, blazing armor, his eyes burning with fury. He addresses his immortal horses, Xanthus and Balius, reproaching them for leaving Patroclus to die and urging them not to abandon him. Xanthus, miraculously given a voice by Juno, warns Achilles that he will die soon, not by their fault but by divine decree. The Furies silence the horse. Achilles, undaunted, accepts his fate and rushes to battle, declaring that Troy shall perish.

**Book XX: The Battle of the Gods, and the Acts of Achilles**
As Achilles prepares for battle, Jupiter calls a council of the gods on Olympus. He grants permission for all deities to assist either the Greeks or the Trojans, fearing that Achilles, unopposed, will take Troy against its fated time. The gods descend to the battlefield. The earth, sea, and Olympus shake from their clash. Pluto, in the underworld, trembles lest the earth open and reveal his realms.

The gods divide: Juno, Neptune, Minerva, Hermes, and Vulcan align with the Greeks; Latona, Apollo, Mars, Diana, and the river god Xanthus (Scamander) with the Trojans. Achilles, glowing with rage, seeks only Hector. Apollo, disguised as Lycaon, encourages Æneas to confront Achilles, reminding him of his divine lineage from Venus. Æneas, initially hesitant due to past defeats, is emboldened.

Juno, seeing Æneas advance, gathers the Greek-aiding gods, fearing Æneas's death might go against fate, as he is destined to found a new Dardan line. Neptune suggests they observe unless gods directly interfere. Æneas and Achilles meet and exchange fierce boasts about their lineages. Æneas throws his spear, striking Achilles' shield but failing to pierce it. Achilles throws his spear, piercing Æneas's shield and grazing him. As Achilles draws his sword for the kill, Neptune, unseen, saves Æneas by shrouding Achilles in darkness, removing his spear from Æneas's shield, and transporting Æneas to the rear of the battle, warning him to avoid Achilles until Achilles' fated death.

Achilles is astonished to find Æneas gone and his spear returned, realizing a god intervened. 8.  **Javelin Throw:** Prizes are a massy spear and an ornate charger. Achilles, honoring Agamemnon's status, awards him the charger, giving Merion the spear.

Priam enters Achilles' tent, prostrates himself, embraces Achilles' knees, and kisses the hands that killed his son. Hermes guides them safely out of the Greek camp.

At dawn, Priam and Idæus return to Troy. Cassandra sees the procession from the walls and alerts the city. The entire city rushes out to meet the wagon, wailing in grief. Priam orders them to take the body to the palace before mourning fully. At the palace, Andromache, Hecuba, and Helen lament over Hector's body. Andromache expresses her sorrow and fears for their son Astyanax. Hecuba praises Hector and notes the divine preservation of his body. Helen mourns Hector as her only kind friend in Troy. Priam then orders the Trojans to gather wood for nine days. On the tenth day, Hector's body is burned on a pyre. His bones are collected in a golden urn and buried under a mound of earth. **The Scarlet Letter: The Plot**

**I. The Prison-Door**
In a new colony, a gloomy, weather-stained wooden prison stands, a symbol of early societal severity. A thorny wild rose-bush, growing by the prison door, offers delicate beauty, perhaps as a symbol of nature's pity.

**II. The Market-Place**
On a summer morning, a stern crowd of Boston's Puritan inhabitants gathers before the prison door. Women in the crowd discuss the expected punishment of Hester Prynne, suggesting harsher measures than what the magistrates typically mete out for "malefactresses." The prison door opens, and Hester Prynne emerges, holding her three-month-old infant, who blinks in the bright daylight, accustomed to the prison's gloom. Hester is a tall, beautiful young woman, who steps forth with an air of natural dignity. On the breast of her elaborate and splendid gown, embroidered with gold thread on fine red cloth, is the letter "A." Her defiant appearance, despite her public shame, astonishes the onlookers. The town-beadle leads Hester through the crowd to a scaffold in the market-place, where she is sentenced to stand for three hours as a public spectacle. As she endures the unrelenting stares, Hester's mind races through memories of her past in Old England: her family home, her parents, her own maiden beauty, and finally, the pale, scholar-like, slightly deformed man she married, with whom she lived in a Continental city. She then returns to the present reality, clutching her baby and touching the scarlet letter, confirming its painful truth.

**III. The Recognition**
Hester's intense focus on the crowd is broken by the sight of a white man standing with an Indian. This white man, small in stature and slightly deformed with one shoulder higher than the other, catches Hester's eye. His face, initially composed, twists in "writhing horror" as he recognizes her, then he quickly controls his expression and subtly gestures for her silence. He asks a townsman about Hester, identifying himself as a stranger who has been a captive among "heathen-folk" and is now brought by the Indian for ransom. The townsman explains Hester is Mistress Prynne, whose husband, Master Prynne, sent her ahead to Boston two years prior but has not been heard from since. The stranger deduces Hester's "evil doings" and the existence of the child, then learns of her sentence to wear the scarlet letter for life because she refuses to name the child's father. The stranger remarks, "A wise sentence! ... He will be known!—he will be known!—he will be known!"

From a balcony above the scaffold, Governor Bellingham, Reverend Mr. Wilson, and Reverend Arthur Dimmesdale observe. Mr. Wilson urges Dimmesdale, Hester's pastor, to compel her to name the father. Dimmesdale, a young, pale, nervous, but eloquent clergyman, earnestly exhorts Hester to confess for her soul's peace and his own, implying the father's hypocrisy. Hester steadfastly refuses, stating the letter is "too deeply branded" and she wishes she could endure "his agony" as well as her own. A voice from the crowd, which Hester recognizes, demands she "give your child a father!" Hester, turning pale, again refuses, declaring her child will seek a "heavenly Father." Dimmesdale, "Wondrous strength and generosity of a woman’s heart! She will not speak!" Mr. Wilson then delivers a long sermon on sin, focusing on the scarlet letter's terrors. Hester endures with stony insensibility, and her infant cries. Hester is led back to prison, the scarlet letter reportedly gleaming luridly in the dark passage.

In prison, Hester is agitated, threatening harm to herself or her baby. Chillingworth admits his own folly in marrying her, a young and beautiful woman, when he was already "in decay" and "misshapen." Hester admits she felt no love for him. Released from prison, Hester chooses to remain in Boston, feeling an irresistible "fatality" to stay near the father of her child. She settles in an isolated cottage on the town's outskirts. Hester lives ascetically, dressing simply, but adorns Pearl in magnificent, fanciful garments, often crimson and gold, which uncannily echo the scarlet letter.

Hester gives her excess earnings to charity, often receiving insults in return. Hester and Pearl pass by, having been at Governor Winthrop's deathbed. Dimmesdale calls them to join him on the scaffold. The three form an "electric chain." Pearl asks if he will stand with them "to-morrow noontide." Dimmesdale, overcome by fear of public exposure, refuses, but promises, "At the great judgment day... thy mother, and thou, and I must stand together." A meteoric "A" appears in the sky, which Dimmesdale's "disordered mental state" interprets as a sign for him. He then sees Pearl pointing at Chillingworth, who has approached the scaffold. Chillingworth's face reveals his "malevolence," and Dimmesdale gasps, "I hate him, Hester!" Hester, bound by her oath, remains silent. Pearl whispers something "gibberish" when asked. Chillingworth, feigning concern, leads Dimmesdale home, attributing his presence on the scaffold to "night-whimseys." The next day, Dimmesdale preaches a powerful sermon, but the sexton finds his glove on the scaffold and reports the "great red letter in the sky," interpreted as "Angel" for the deceased Governor Winthrop.

**XIII. Another View of Hester**
Hester is shocked by Dimmesdale's frail condition and realizes Chillingworth's torment is destroying him. After seven years of enduring public infamy, Hester has earned a measure of public respect through her charity and quiet dignity. The scarlet letter is now often interpreted as "Able," a symbol of her strength and helpfulness as a "Sister of Mercy." However, her own character has become cold and intellectual. She is now resolved to reveal Chillingworth's true identity to Dimmesdale, recognizing her responsibility to rescue him from her former husband's grip. She finds Chillingworth gathering herbs in the forest.

**XIV. Hester and the Physician**
Hester sends Pearl to play by the brook and confronts Chillingworth. He informs her that the magistrates have discussed removing her scarlet letter, but Hester believes it must fall off naturally if she is worthy. Hester observes Chillingworth's transformation into an "eager, searching, almost fierce" and evil man, a "devil" consumed by revenge. She tells him she made a "heavy wrong" by keeping his secret, enabling his torment of Dimmesdale. Chillingworth boasts he has kept Dimmesdale alive to suffer, becoming a "fiend" for his "especial torment." Hester cries that it would have been "Better he had died at once!" Chillingworth, in a moment of self-awareness, sees his own moral ruin. Hester, admitting her shared culpability in his transformation, declares her intention to reveal his true character to Dimmesdale. Chillingworth, unable to pardon, says his hatred is their "fate" and tells Hester to "deal as thou wilt with yonder man."

**XV. Hester and Pearl**
Hester reflects on her hatred for Chillingworth, seeing his manipulation as a greater wrong than her own sin. Pearl returns, having made a green "A" from seaweed for her own breast. Pearl acutely observes that Dimmesdale keeps his hand over his heart "for the same reason that the minister keeps his hand over his heart!" Hester is unsettled by Pearl's insight. Pearl presses her mother to explain the scarlet letter and the minister's gesture. Hester deflects the questions, angered by Pearl's persistence.

**XVI. A Forest Walk**
Hester resolves to tell Dimmesdale about Chillingworth. She meets him in the forest. Dimmesdale appears haggard and feeble. Pearl notes the sunshine avoids Hester and runs to play in it herself. Pearl asks Hester about the "Black Man" who haunts the forest and marks people with his symbol. Hester admits, "Once in my life I met the Black Man! This scarlet letter is his mark!" Pearl then asks if Dimmesdale keeps his hand over his heart because the Black Man marked him there. Hester sends Pearl away to play.

**XVII. The Pastor and His Parishioner**
Hester calls out to Dimmesdale. They meet in the dim forest, like ghosts. Dimmesdale confesses he has found "nothing but despair," tormented by his hidden sin and the people's reverence. He longs for someone to know him as the "vilest of all sinners," as the truth would save him from "falsehood!—all emptiness!—all death!" Hester reveals that Chillingworth, the physician, is her husband. Dimmesdale reacts with a fierce frown and collapses, blaming Hester. Hester, embracing him, pleads for his forgiveness, which he eventually grants, saying Chillingworth's revenge is "blacker than my sin." They sit hand-in-hand, contemplating their escape. Hester urges him to leave Chillingworth, to flee into the wilderness or across the sea, to start a new life as a teacher or scholar. Dimmesdale feels too weak to go alone. Hester whispers, "Thou shalt not go alone!"

**XVIII. A Flood of Sunshine**
Dimmesdale is filled with a mixture of hope, joy, and fear at Hester's daring proposal to flee together. Hester, having lived outside societal norms, feels free to speculate on a new life. Dimmesdale, constrained by his past and profession, struggles with the idea. He resolves to flee with Hester. Hester unclasps the scarlet letter from her bosom and throws it away among the leaves. The burden of shame lifts, her beauty and youthful warmth return, and the gloomy forest is suddenly filled with sunshine. She urges Dimmesdale to accept Pearl. Dimmesdale expresses unease with children but remembers Pearl's rare kindness to him. Hester calls Pearl, who approaches slowly.

**XIX. The Child at the Brook-Side**
Hester and Dimmesdale watch Pearl. Dimmesdale admits his fear that Pearl's features reveal their shared sin. Pearl reaches the brook, but will not cross it. She points at Hester's bare bosom and then at her own green "A" made of seaweed. Hester realizes Pearl expects her to wear the scarlet letter. Dimmesdale, agitated, urges Hester to pacify the child. Hester retrieves the scarlet letter from the leaves and re-fastens it to her bosom. Immediately, her beauty and cheerfulness vanish, replaced by a "gray shadow." Pearl then bounds across the brook, embraces Hester, and kisses her, but also kisses the scarlet letter, causing Hester anguish. Pearl asks if Dimmesdale will walk with them, "hand in hand, we three together, into the town?" Hester promises a future home, but says "Not now, dear child." Pearl asks if the minister will "always keep his hand over his heart?" Pearl, perhaps out of jealousy, refuses Dimmesdale's embrace and washes off his kiss in the brook. Hester and Dimmesdale make plans for their departure.

**XX. The Minister in a Maze**
Dimmesdale departs, reflecting on his decision to flee with Hester and Pearl to Europe on a ship sailing in three days, after he delivers his Election Sermon. He experiences a strange sense of unreality and a revolution in his inner being, feeling impulses to commit strange, wicked acts. He barely restrains himself from blasphemous remarks to a deacon, from suggesting atheistic ideas to an old church member, from corrupting a young maiden he converted, from teaching wicked words to children, and from carousing with a drunken sailor. Mistress Hibbins confronts him, hinting at his secret forest meeting with the "Black Man" and asserting that his hidden mark will be revealed. Dimmesdale questions if he has sold himself to the fiend. He returns to his study, finding it strange, and recognizes that his "former self was gone." Chillingworth enters, and Dimmesdale, despite feigning health, realizes Chillingworth knows his secret. Dimmesdale rejects Chillingworth's medical help, feeling a new strength. Alone, he burns his old Election Sermon and writes a new, inspired one all night with intense ecstasy.

**XXI. The New England Holiday**
On Election Day, Hester and Pearl are in the market-place, which is bustling with townspeople, Indians, and mariners. Hester wears her gray dress and the scarlet letter, which, after seven years, is a familiar, though still potent, symbol. She feels a sense of quiet triumph, anticipating her freedom. Pearl is adorned in magnificent, brightly colored clothes, her vivacity reflecting her mother's hidden agitation. Pearl observes the festive scene, asking why everyone is merry and if the minister will greet them. Hester tells her he will not greet them publicly. Pearl observes the minister still keeps his hand over his heart. Mistress Hibbins again appears, hinting at Dimmesdale's secret compact with the "Black Man" and predicting his mark will be revealed. Pearl eagerly asks about this.

A procession of magistrates, soldiers, and ministers approaches for the Election Sermon. Roger Chillingworth is seen in familiar conversation with the shipmaster of the Bristol vessel. The shipmaster later tells Hester that Chillingworth has arranged to sail with them on the same ship, claiming to be "of your party, and a close friend to the gentleman you spoke of." Hester is inwardly alarmed by this news, realizing Chillingworth has discovered their escape plan. She sees Chillingworth smiling ominously across the market-place.

**XXII. The Procession**
The procession begins with music and military escort. Mr. Dimmesdale appears, walking with unusual energy and an abstracted, inspired air, showing no sign of feebleness or his hand on his heart. Hester watches, feeling his remoteness and questioning if their forest plans were a delusion. Pearl asks if it was the same minister who kissed her by the brook, noting his changed demeanor in public. Mistress Hibbins again approaches Hester, revealing her knowledge of Dimmesdale's secret forest activities with the "Black Man" and predicting his mark will be exposed to the world. Pearl eagerly questions Mistress Hibbins about this. Hester, compelled by an "irresistible feeling," stands beside the scaffold, listening to Dimmesdale's eloquent Election Sermon. His powerful voice, even when muffled, conveys a deep "cry of pain."

**XXIII. The Revelation of the Scarlet Letter**
Dimmesdale's sermon concludes with immense public acclaim. He stands at the height of his professional triumph, hailed as a saint. As the procession moves towards the town-hall banquet, Dimmesdale appears feeble and pale, his strength seemingly drained. He rejects Mr. Wilson's offer of support. Dimmesdale, tottering, approaches the scaffold where Hester and Pearl stand. Governor Bellingham moves to assist him, but Dimmesdale's expression warns him back.

Dimmesdale calls Hester and Pearl to him. Pearl flies to his knees, and Hester slowly approaches. Roger Chillingworth rushes forward, trying to stop Dimmesdale, whispering, "Madman, hold! what is your purpose?... I can yet save you!" Dimmesdale, confronting Chillingworth, declares, "Ha, tempter! Methinks thou art too late! ... With God’s help, I shall escape thee now!" He calls on Hester for her strength to help him ascend the scaffold, despite Chillingworth's opposition.

Leaning on Hester and holding Pearl's hand, Dimmesdale ascends the scaffold. Chillingworth follows, lamenting that Dimmesdale has escaped him on this very scaffold. Dimmesdale, trembling, asks Hester if this public revelation is better than their forest dream; she replies, "I know not!" Dimmesdale declares himself a dying man and makes haste to "take my shame upon me!"

He addresses the appalled multitude, confessing he is "the one sinner of the world!" He states he should have stood there seven years ago with Hester and that the scarlet letter she wears is but a "shadow of what he bears on his own breast." With a convulsive motion, he tears open his ministerial band, revealing a scarlet letter (or its semblance) imprinted in his flesh. The crowd is horror-stricken. Dimmesdale, with a "flush of triumph," collapses onto the scaffold. Hester supports him. Chillingworth kneels beside him, distraught, repeating, "Thou hast escaped me!" Dimmesdale, dying, tells Chillingworth, "May God forgive thee! Thou, too, hast deeply sinned!"

Dimmesdale turns to Pearl, asking for a kiss, which she previously refused in the forest. Pearl kisses his lips, breaking a "spell." Her tears fall on his cheek, symbolizing her transition to womanhood, capable of human joy and sorrow. Her "errand as a messenger of anguish" to her mother is fulfilled. Hester asks if they will meet again in immortal life. Dimmesdale, with "tremulous solemnity," says their broken law and revealed sin make it vain to hope for a pure reunion, and that God's mercy was shown through his tortures and this "death of triumphant ignominy." He dies with a final "Farewell!" The multitude murmurs in awe.

**XXIV. Conclusion**
After Dimmesdale's death, multiple accounts circulate regarding what was seen on his breast. Most witnesses reported a scarlet letter imprinted in his flesh, attributed to self-inflicted penance, Chillingworth's magic, or the gnawing of remorse. However, some spectators, particularly his friends, denied any mark, claiming Dimmesdale's death was a parable teaching humility and God's mercy. The narrator, referencing Surveyor Pue's manuscript, affirms the existence of the mark, and concludes with the moral: "Be true! Be true! Be true! Show freely to the world, if not your worst, yet some trait whereby the worst may be inferred!"

Roger Chillingworth, his purpose of revenge now "consummated," withers away and dies within a year. His considerable property is bequeathed to little Pearl. Pearl, now a rich heiress, and Hester then disappear. Years later, Hester Prynne returns to her old cottage in Boston, still wearing the scarlet letter. There are indications (letters, luxuries, a baby-garment embroidered by Hester) that Pearl is alive, married, happy, and mindful of her mother, living in another land. Hester chooses to remain in New England, resuming the scarlet letter, which over time loses its stigma and becomes a symbol of awe and reverence. Women, burdened by their own sorrows and passions, seek Hester's counsel. Hester offers comfort and expresses her belief that a "new truth" will one day establish a better relationship between man and woman, to be revealed by a "lofty, pure, and beautiful" prophetess.
